Speaker.P: Deputy Shatter has given me notice of his intention to raise the matter of the circumstances resulting in two persons being held in a cell in Castlebar Garda station which contained firearms and ammunition; whether an inquiry is being conducted into this incident and if he would outline the steps, if any, being taken to ensure that such weapons and ammunition are not similarly stored in the future.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Shatter Mr. Shatter
Speaker.P: Thank you, Sir, for giving me to the opportunity to raise what appears on the face of it be a bizarre and extraordinary event. As is already widely known, the present Minister for Justice has been somewhat unfortunate in that apparently he was the victim of a burglary in his private residence prior to Christmas, which we were all sorry to hear. Indeed, one would have expected that the security on his home in Dublin would have prevented that happening. That was an unfortunate event but that misfortune apparently has been compounded by a degree of carelessness which is difficult to fathom.

MainHeading.P: There were widespread reports last week that two persons, allegedly arrested for being drunk and disorderly, were placed in the cells of the Garda station in Castlebar. Incredibly, the reports stated, it was subsequently discovered that within the cell in which the two people were placed were 20,000 rounds of ammunition, an Uzi submachine gun and five hand guns. Reportedly there was some commotion in the cell some time after the two allegedly inebriated gentlemen were placed in it which resulted in a garda in the station returning to the cell to find the two gentlemen somewhat the worse for wear and reportedly each waving a hand gun in the air. I am assuming that the hand guns had no ammunition in them. I am also assuming that the gentlemen concerned were so badly inebriated they did not know the nature of what they were doing, were not quite sure whether they were in a cell or playing a game of cowboys and indians down in Castlebar.

Events such as this occurring in the Minister's home town are a matter of some considerable embarrassment. But it is a matter of great concern — and I emphasise the word “concern”— that ammunition and guns could be stored in such a careless way that events could evolve which resulted in two persons being incarcerated in a cell in which it is alleged, guns and ammunition were stored. If the reports are true it is fortunate that the two people placed in the cell were not from a subversive organisation. We can thank God that was not the case. Had they been from a subversive organisation God only knows what could have been the consequences of the events which took place in Castlebar on that reported occasion.

It is my hope that the Minister will tell me this is all fiction invented by the news media and/or a grossly exaggerated event. It would be of some relief to learn that was the case. If that was the case, the silence of the Department of Justice last week, when these reports became public, is quite peculiar. It would seem to me that rather than this issue having to be raised in this House a statement should have been issued from the Minister's office last week detailing the exact nature of the events that occurred and giving assurances that necessary precautions would be put in place to ensure there is no repetition.

I am asking for those assurances. I am asking the Minister to detail to the House the exact events that occurred and what inquiry, if any, is being conducted into them. Perhaps the Minister will be in a position to indicate what has befallen the two inebriated gentlemen who, I understand from press reports, were eventually released and against whom no charges were brought. I am not suggesting that charges should be brought against them. I am merely saying that we were extraordinarily lucky that, in these series of events — which could have been well written in a Tom Sharpe novel — no serious injuries were sustained and no life lost. Indeed, we are lucky that the gardaí were not injured. We are equally lucky that the two gentlemen who found themselves locked up with so much ammunition did not injure themselves or each other, considering their alleged condition.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of the Gaeltacht and at the Department of the Marine (Mr. Gallagher) Minister of State at the Department of the Gaeltacht and at the Department of the Marine (Mr. Gallagher)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of the Gaeltacht and at the Department of the Marine (Mr. Gallagher)
Speaker.P: Bá mhaith liom leithscéal an Aire Dlí agus Cirt agus an Aire Stáit a ghabháil as ucht nach bhfuil sé ar a gcumas bheith anseo.

The matter raised in the House tonight by Deputy Shatter has been the subject of very serious allegations reported in the media. The nature of these allegations is that persons arrested on the morning of 28 May, 1992, were placed and held in a cell in Castlebar Garda station which contained firearms and ammunition. These allegations are of a very serious nature. I have no wish to downplay that in any way. At the same time, it is important to bear in mind that we are speaking of allegations, no more than that at this point.

The Garda authorities have ordered a full investigation into what happened in Castlebar station on the morning of 28 May. I can assure the House that the investigation, which is being conducted by a senior officer from outside the Mayo Garda Division, is already well under way and will be completed with all possible speed. This officer will inquire into the circumstances of all detentions at Castlebar Garda station on the night in question and endeavour to establish whether there is substance to the allegations reported in the media. He will review the procedures relating to the storage of firearms and consider whether these procedures were implemented on the morning in question.

MainHeading.P: Pending completion of this officer's investigation it would not be appropriate to comment further on this matter other than to inform the House that, should recommendations for safer storage of firearms emerge from the review — and in saying that I am not to be taken as in any way prejudging anything or implying an absence of safety on the morning in question — these recommendations will be given effect by the Garda authorities. I repeat that the investigation is at present under way. It is hoped that it will be completed with all possible speed when we will be in a position to report further.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Shatter Mr. Shatter
Speaker.P: Six weeks have expired since the reported incident. It is bizarre that the Minister cannot tell the House exactly what happened.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: Please, Deputy Shatter, desist. We must continue to the next matter.

MainHeading.Title: Adjournment Debate. - Threat of Disruption of School Transport System.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Ryan Mr. Ryan
Speaker.P: First, I wish to thank you, Sir, for affording me the opportunity of raising this issue in the House this evening. The future of school transport is a matter of grave concern not only to hundreds of thousands of parents nationwide but also to nearly 1,000 employees of Bus Éireann and to 1,600 private contractors directly involved in the operations and administration of the service.

MainHeading.P: It is timely that I raise this matter given the controversy that has arisen as a direct consequence of the Minister's desire to privatise the service. His proposals for the devolution of management and administration of the service to private contractors, local authorities or schools, boards of management is a recipe for disaster, would ultimately incur more costs for the State and would be less effective overall. It would also lead to a duplication of service and lack of standards. Many small, rural areas will be affected and many jobs put at risk.

Over the years various Governments have commissioned reports on the operation of the school bus service. In 1970 we had the Hyland report. In 1980 there were various interdepartmental reports. In the late eighties we had a pilot scheme. In August of that same year Bus Éireann were requested to pick up the tab to bring the service back under its wing. In 1990 the Departments of Education and Tourism, Transport and Communications commissioned Deloitte and Touche to produce a report. Let me briefly quote a number of the recommendations. One states that the provision of the school bus service by Bus Éireann is, in their opinion, at or near the minimum cost for the level of service provided under the present rules of the scheme. Another stated that the supervision and management of the school bus transport network is a complex but stable task and that in their opinion it is well carried out by Bus Éireann. The report also stated that Bus Eireann deliver the yellow bus element of the scheme at direct costs which are competitive with those operating in the private sector of public transport.

How can the Minister disregard the main recommendations of this report? It seems, given his decision to seek a further report, that it is his intention to continue to commission costly reports until such time as one comes up with the conditions and the recommendations that he is looking for. In view of this, is it any wonder that the trade unions representing the staff, particularly SIPTU and the TSSA, are taking a very strong line on this matter. It should be of deep concern to the Minister that the board of CIE are threatening to put the workforce directly involved on protective notice if the problems are not resolved satisfactorily.

The annual piecemeal approach to the school bus service is most frustrating to the staff and is not conducive to a continuity of service. I recommend that the Minister accept the Deloitte and Touche recommendations and meet with management and unions with a view to putting the school bus service in this country on a sound footing once and for all. There is a deep resentment in the company at the directive that Bus Eireann should not enter into commitments regarding school transport beyond the end of this year. This is totally unworkable. I would ask the Minister to withdraw it.

The State owes nearly £4.6 million to Bus Éireann for the operation of the school transport service and this is putting a grave strain on their resources. Hopefully the Minister will be able to give a commitment to have this matter resolved.

It is reported in the media that substantial increases in charges for school transport have been recommended by the Department of Education from January next. An increase of the order of £19 per pupil per term which would bring it from £21 to £40 for junior cycle pupils and from £35 to £55 for senior cycle pupils are the figures quoted. Increases of this magnitude will have a devastating effect on the families of some 164,000 school-going children who use the transport service. This is totally unacceptable and the Labour Party will be totally opposed to it.

I would ask the Minister to bring to the attention of the Minister for Education my concern that a proper service should be introduced. All the resources of the people in the Department should be called on to ensure that the best service is provided. I believe the Minister has taken the option he himself wishes, the option of privatisation. This is not the solution to this problem and I hope the Minister will take on board the views expressed here tonight and hopefully will give some good news when he is replying.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gallagher Mr. Gallagher
Speaker.P: As far as the Department of Education are concerned, they expect the school transport scheme to operate normally in accordance with current procedures as from September next. These procedures are based on an agreement between the Department and Bus Éireann under which Bus Eireann act as agent for the Department in the operation of the school transport scheme. The Department establish the policies related to the scheme and it is a matter for Bus Éireann to operate the scheme within those policies.

The scheme has been operating now for 24 years. In view of the costs involved and the complexities of the arrangements necessary to cater for a wide diversity of requirements, the operation of the scheme is kept under continual review. A recent consultancy study found that on the basis of current arrangements the scheme was operated cost-efficiently by Bus Éireann. The review is continuing to determine whether any alternative arrangements could provide greater efficiency and effectiveness.

Let me stress that what is in question is a continuing review, again with the assistance of consultants. The next phase of the review is not yet started and will include consultation with concerned interests. There is no question of any decisions having been taken. Such decisions would be a matter solely for Government, following completion of the review. Such decisions, if any, will be for the future. In so far as the coming school year is concerned, I expect, as I have stated, the school transport scheme to proceed under the normal procedures and arrangements as agreed between the Department of Education and Bus Éireann.

MainHeading.Title: Adjournment Debate. - Social Welfare and Justice Matters.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: The House will now hear two minute statements on matters appropriate to the Minister for Social Welfare and the Minister for Justice. I propose to call the Deputies I have selected in the following order: Deputy Nealon, Deputy Bell and Deputy Deasy in respect of matters to the Minister for Social Welfare and, again, Deputy Deasy in respect of matters to the Minister for Justice. The House will now hear a two minute statement from Deputy Nealon.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Nealon Mr. Nealon
Speaker.P: I am very glad of this opportunity of bringing to the attention of the Minister for Social Welfare what I regard as a monstrous anomaly in the social welfare code. The reason I am raising it in the House at this time is in direct response to a call for some sort of action by a constituent of mine who is a victim of this regulation. This is as much about principle as it is about money.

My constituent is now on maternity benefit, as she was almost two years or so ago. Now she finds she is getting less money than she did the last time even though she is on a higher salary. The reason is that she worked for only 38 weeks in the present reckonable tax year which happened to be the year of her previous maternity leave. If she had had her maternity leave a little earlier or a little later she would be getting 70 per cent of a full year's salary and not, as now, 70 per cent of 38 weeks' salary.

Surely there is something wrong with that kind of thinking, that a previous maternity leave should be a factor in the calculation of the benefit in a subsequent maternity leave just because of a confluence of timings. I understand that this kind of anomaly may be dealt with in a new EC Directive, but the Minister should not wait for Europe to tell us what to do in a matter such as this.

We all, I suppose, are familiar with the considerations and difficulties involved in family planning. Surely we should not be adding the reckonable tax year as a further calendar calculation that has to be done.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gallagher Mr. Gallagher
Speaker.P: Maternity benefit is payable to women in employment, including women in employment under a contract for a fixed term and to women in part-time employment earning £25 or more per week, subject to certain PRSI contribution conditions. The weekly rate of social insurance maternity allowance payment is 70 per cent of the claimant's average reckonable weekly earnings in the relevant tax year, subject to a minimum payment of £60 per week and a maximum payment of £154 per week. The relevant tax year, for the purposes of calculating average reckonable weekly earnings, is the last complete income tax year before the beginning of the benefit, that is, the calendar year in which the first day of maternity leave occurs. Therefore, for a maternity benefit claim commencing during the benefit year January-December 1992, the relevant income tax year is 1990-91.

Maternity benefit is not treated as income for the purpose of determining avarage reckonable earnings. However, the minimum payment of £60 under the scheme ensures that recipients whose earnings in the relevant tax year are low do not have their entitlements reduced below the level of other analogous social welfare payments.

The scheme, therefore, guarantees a minimum payment for low income earners who would otherwise have received a significantly lower payment as a result of having been in receipt of maternity benefit in the reckonable tax year.

An EC Directive concerning the protection of pregnant workers is currently under consideration. It is expected that this Directive will be adopted before the end of 1992. The draft Directive lays down certain minima in terms of social security protection for pregnant workers, which are already exceeded by the entitlements applying to Irish workers. The maternity benefit scheme will be reviewed in the light of the Directive once it is adopted and the issue raised here will be considered in that context. However, any changes in the maternity benefit scheme would have to be considered in a budgetary context.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: It was expected that we should now have a two-minute statement from Deputy Michael Bell. I do not observe the Deputy. I am proceeding, therefore, to call Deputy Austin Deasy to make his two-minute statement.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: I raise this issue because it defies explanation. It arises as a result of the Social Welfare Act recently passed by this House. I regret that the Minister for Social Welfare, Deputy McCreevy, is not in the House to hear the case I wish to make. I do not want him to answer the case as such but I want to request him to repeal the legislation.

This issue concerns a single man in my constituency of Waterford who has been working and stamping a card for the past 27 years. Since he became sick ten years ago he has been receiving a disability benefit of £50 per week. He told me that he thought he should be getting much more assistance. When I made inquiries at the local social welfare office I was informed that, as a result of the Social Welfare Act recently passed by this House, that was his maximum entitlement. I then contacted the TDs' complaints section in the Department of Social Welfare who merely confirmed what the local office had told me, that the maximum payment for a single man on disability benefit is £50.

I wish to refer to the anomaly in this case. If this man was unemployed and had never worked he would be entitled to receive £55 per week. However, having paid 27 years' stamps and worked hard all his life he is now being penalised to the extent of £5 per week; he is receiving less for having worked and stamped a card than if he had never worked at all. I cannot see the justice in that. I request the Minister to change the legislation so that this wrong can be corrected.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Finance (Mr. N. Treacy) Noel Treacy
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Finance (Mr. N. Treacy)
Speaker.P: The Minister for Social Welfare would have liked to be present in the House but he is detained elsewhere on Government business. He has asked me to deputise for him. The Social Welfare improvements announced in the 1991 budget provided for a general 4 per cent increase in all weekly payments with effect from the end of July 1991. However, special increases of 11 per cent were given to those in receipt of short term unemployment assistance and 6 per cent to those getting the long term rate of unemployment assistance. The effect of those increases was to ensure a minimum personal rate of £50 for all short term payments and £55 for all long term payments.

As a result, since July 1991 the personal rates of all long term payments have reached or exceeded the priority rate recommended by the Commission on Social Welfare. The Programme for Economic and Social Progress contains a specific commitment to move by 1993 to the priority level of rates recommended by the Commission on Social Welfare.

A PRSI contributor who falls sick and claims disability benefit would, subject to satisfying the relevant conditions, receive a personal rate of £50 per week. The same person who loses his or her job and claims unemployment benefit would receive the same weekly rate of payment, subject to satisfying the relevant conditions. Where the person continues to be unemployed for more than 15 months, unemployment assistance at the long term rate of £55 per week becomes payable subject to satisfying a means test.

I accept the point made by the Deputy that an unemployed person with no means, who has never paid PRSI contributions and who is in receipt of the maximum rate of long term unemployment assistance is better off by £5 per week than the PRSI contributor who becomes sick and claims disability benefit. This differential of £5 per week is designed to recognise the special needs of the long term unemployed and is in line with the policy of providing higher payments to long term recipients in general.

MainHeading.P: I have to take issue with the point made by Deputy Deasy that no recognition has been given to the contributions made by the applicant. On reaching a certain age or becoming sick a person can draw either disability benefit, invalidity pension or contributory or retirement pension based on their contribution. Obviously, they are in a much better position at certain times——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: That is if they reach the age.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: They will certainly be in a much more advantageous position than a person who is unemployed on a long term basis.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: It is an appalling wrong which has to be rectified.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: The House will now hear a further two-minute statement from Deputy Deasy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deasy Mr. Deasy
Speaker.P: With a huge young population, many of whom are unemployed, there is a growing crime problem in this country. It has been obvious for some time that conventional policing is not sufficient to deal with growing vandalism, drug abuse and violent behaviour, particularly in urban areas. I suggest that the Garda Síochána be assisted in their duties by a reserve force, equal in number to the strength of the present force which is approximately 10,000. Special attention should be paid to obvious flashpoints such as pub closing times, social and sporting events and assisting in community work.

MainHeading.P: At present many crimes go unreported because the public believe the Garda will never have time to solve their problem or even investigate it. This complaint is continually made to me. I regard the alternative to my proposal as unacceptable. If present policing practices and presence are not improved vigilante groups will take the law into their own hands, thereby creating more problems than will be solved. I firmly believe there are enough civic-minded people available to constitute such a force. This force would not patrol or act at any time without being supervised by a regular member of the Garda.

The time has come to recognise that the present system is not adequate to deal with a worsening problem. We should face up to the fact that law and order has broken down and tackle the problem realistically. In other words, I am asking that a part-time civilian force be set up, as is the case in many other countries, to augment and assist the Garda in the performance of their duties.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gallagher Mr. Gallagher
Speaker.P: It has always been the policy of successive Governments and the Garda authorities to encourage all law-abiding and responsible citizens to assist the Garda in law enforcement. The question of the establishment of a reserve police force has been examined from time to time. However, it is not clear that any possible advantage arising from the establishment of such a force would outweigh potential difficulties which could arise from it. For example, one would have to be concerned with the rights of individuals faced with a new law enforcement group who would initially lack the expertise and training of full-time police. With regard to the need for additional gardaí, recruitment of 1,000 gardaí over the next few years is already under way. In addition, 585 civilian clerical staff are employed in the Garda Síochána. This is a matter which the Minister is pursuing in consultation with the Garda authorities.
The Dáil adjourned at 11.45 p.m. until 10.30 a.m. on Wednesday, 8 July 1992.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Northern Ireland Talks.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. O'Keeffe Mr. J. O'Keeffe
Qst.Quest: if he will make a statement on the progress to date of the Northern Ireland talks.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. O'Keeffe Mr. J. O'Keeffe
Qst.Quest: if he will make a statement on current political developments in Northern Ireland.

Qst.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Qst.Quest: if he will outline (1) the matters discussed at his meeting in London on 30 June with the British Government and representatives of Northern Ireland parties and (2) his assessment of the prospects for progress in the Northern Ireland talks in light of his discussions; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 18, 60 and 78 together.

MainHeading.P: The Government warmly welcomed the proposal by Sir Patrick Mayhew on 1 July that Strands Two and Three should now be launched and the acceptance of this proposal by the four political parties participating in the Talks process.

Strand Two is a very important and integral part of the process which was agreed on 26 March 1991. We are pleased that this critical phase of the talks has now been reached. The Government look forward to working actively and constructively in Strand Two, the opening session of which is underway at present under the independent Chairmanship of Sir Ninian Stephen.

The meeting to discuss a possible agenda for Strand Two was held in London on 19 June under the Chairmanship of Sir Ninian. Both Governments were represented at official level and with the four political parties also participating. Agreement was reached on a draft Agenda for Strand Two.

At the meeting in Strand Three formation which took place in London on 30 June under the joint chairmanship of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Secretary of State for Northern Ireland, agreement was reached between the two Governments on a possible agenda for Strand Three.
Statements were also made by observers from each of the four parties. Deputies will understand if I am unable to enter into detail about the discussions which took place.
As indicated on previous occasions, the Government are bound by the obligation of confidentiality which is imposed on every participant in the Talks.
We have strictly adhered to this requirement and will continue to do so, not least in the interest of a successful outcome to the Talks.

The agreed object of this Talks process is to “achieve a new beginning for relationships within Northern Ireland, within the island of Ireland and between people of these islands”. The Government will do all in its power to promote the realisation of that objective.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. O'Keeffe Mr. J. O'Keeffe
Qst.Quest: whether Ireland has made any proposals on the non-proliferation and reduction of nuclear weapons now that thousands of such weapons are stored in the different republics of the former Soviet Union and that highly skilled redundant nuclear scientists are available to pariah nations to assist them in putting together nuclear weapons capacity.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: The Government's commitment to nuclear non-proliferation and to the reduction and ultimate elimination of nuclear weapons is well known.

The Government have been concerned that the transformation of the former Soviet Union into the Commonwealth of Independent States should not lead to any increase in the number of nuclear weapon States or contribute in any way to the proliferation of nuclear weapons. Bilaterally and together with our partners in the European Community, Ireland has made this concern clear to the CIS Republics.

In their Declaration of 16 December 1991 on the “Guidelines on the recognition of new States in Eastern Europe and in the Soviet Union”, the Foreign Ministers of the Twelve listed as a precondition for recognition of a new State “acceptance of all relevant commitments with regard to disarmament and nuclear non-proliferation as well as to security and regional stability”.

MainHeading.P: In their statement on the “Future Status of Russia and other former Soviet Republics” dated 23 December 1991, the Community and its member states again clearly stated their expectation of assurances from the CIS republics to “ensure single control over nuclear weapons and their non-proliferation”. Finally, in the statement on the “Recognition of former Soviet Republics” of 31 December 1991, the Community and its member states expressed their readiness to proceed with recognition on the basis of the assurances received and on the understanding that all republics “on whose territory nuclear weapons are stationed, will adhere to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty as non-nuclear States”.

As the Deputy is no doubt aware, nuclear weapons are stationed on the territory of four of the CIS republics: Russia, Belarus, Ukraine and Kazakhstan. These four republics have agreed that there should be a single command over all their nuclear forces. The Government welcome the announcements by Belarus, Ukraine and Kazakhstan and that they will accede to the Non-Proliferation Treaty as non-nuclear States and that all of the nuclear weapons on their territories will be eliminated. The Government also welcome the agreement signed in Washington recently by Presidents Bush and Yeltsin which provides for substantial further reductions in nuclear weapons by the year 2003.

The Government have also been concerned that States which are known to be developing their own nuclear weapons might seek to acquire nuclear materials, equipment or expertise from the CIS States. The Government have encouraged the CIS republics to introduce effective export controls to ensure that nuclear materials and equipment are not acquired for military purposes.

Together with our European partners, Ireland has also contributed to the establishment of the International Science and Technology Centre in Russia which is intended to provide opportunities for Soviet nuclear scientists and engineers to redirect their talents to peaceful nuclear activities so as to ensure that they will not be recruited by other countries seeking to develop their own nuclear weapons. The European Community will contribute 20 million ECUs towards the cost of setting up this Centre which will make a significant contribution to nuclear non-proliferation objectives.

Qst.hpid: Mr. M. Higgins Mr. M. Higgins
Qst.Quest: if he will outline the Irish Government's view in relation to the present political position in Algeria.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: The Minister for Foreign Affairs has conveyed to the Foreign Minister of Algeria the sincerest sympathy of the Irish Government and his shock at the assassination on 29 June of Mr. Mohammed Boudiaf, President of the High State Committee of Algeria.

The Government, together with their partners in the European Community, has been greatly concerned at developments in Algeria since the beginning of 1992, when the second round of the parliamentary elections scheduled for 16 January were cancelled. That decision was followed by the declaration of a State of Emergency, large scale arrests and now the assassination of Mr. Boudiaf.

European Community Foreign Ministers issued a Declaration on 17 February underlining the need for steps to be taken by the Algerian authorities to restore the democratic process. The Foreign Ministers also made clear the importance they attached to ensuring respect for human rights, tolerance and political pluralism. The European Council, at their meeting in Lisbon on 26-27 June, made a major Declaration on relations between Europe and the countries of the Maghreb region, including Algeria. That Declaration sets out the principles on which those relations are to be based, and demonstrates clearly that progress must be made towards free elections and that whoever is the victor in those elections must govern on the basis of respect for human rights and the rights of minorities and must be committed to the holding of regular elections.

It is the Government's strong hope that the Algerian authorities will undertake every possible effort for a return to normal institutional life so that peaceful political dialogue among all parties concerned will take place and democracy be restored there.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - WEU Permanent Observer Status.

Qst.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Qst.Quest: if, in regard to the reported comments of the Taoiseach to political correspondents on 28 May, he will outline when a decision was made to apply for permanent observer status to the Western European Union; when the application was lodged; when it is likely to be considered; the reason the information regarding the application was not given to the Dáil; if he intends to seek the approval of the Oireachtas for the application; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Western European Union.

Qst.Quest: if, in view of the outcome of the referendum on the Treaty on European Union, he will make a definitive statement on Ireland's future role in the Western European Union.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 29 and 64 together.

MainHeading.P: In their Declaration made at Maastricht on 10 December of last year, the member states of the Western European Union proposed that States which are members of the European Union be invited to accede to the Western European Union or become observers. At their most recent meeting in Bonn on 19 June, Western European Union Ministers agreed to extend invitations to prospective members, observers and associates. This invitation was communicated to the Minister for Foreign Affairs by the German Foreign Minister, as President of the Western European Union, on 30 June. As both the Taoiseach and I have stated on a number of occasions, the Government do not propose that Ireland should become a member of the Western European Union. However, we do see advantages in taking up observer status. As an observer, we would be able to ensure that Ireland was fully informed of developments in the Western European Union that might have bearing on discussions in European Union. This would place the Government in a better position to formulate appropriate responses on such issues within the European Union. It would also help the Government to decide on the reference of issues with defence implications to the Western European Union and enable Ireland to follow the subsequent discussions within the Western European Union on such issues.

I would again underline that, as an observer in the Western European Union, we would not have to take up any commitments under the Western European Union Treaty or subscribe to any policy positions or platforms adopted by the Western European Union.
The Government will be pursuing the invitation with the incoming Italian Presidency of the Western European Union and I will keep the House informed of developments.

whether, following the vote by the Irish people on the Maastricht Treaty, he will outline the proposals the Government have for the shape of the 1996 Treaty.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 30, 33, 37, 39, 41, 42, 43, 51, 52, 57, 67, 69 and 72 together.

Article N (2) of the Treaty on European Union provides for the convening of a conference of representatives of the Governments of the member states in 1996 to examine the provisions of the Treaty for which revision is provided, in accordance with the objectives set out in Articles A and B of the Treaty. As well as this, under Article N (1) it is open to the Government of any member state or to the Commission to submit to the Council proposals for the amendment of the Treaties.
The Intergovernmental Conferences which negotiated the Treaty on European Union agreed that the following areas will be included in the 1996 review:
—the scope of the co-decision procedure;
—competence in the areas of energy, civil protection and tourism;
—common foreign and security policy; and
—measures to enhance the democratic process in the operation of the Treaty.

MainHeading.P: Preparations for the conference provided for in Article N will not begin until the Treaty on European Union is fully operative.

When preparations begin, consideration will be given to whether any proposals for amendment or review should be proposed by Ireland. The circumstances of the Community are likely to be different in 1996 from what they are today.
Firstly, amendment or review of the provisions of the Treaty will have to be considered in the light of the operation experience of the Treaty.

Secondly, the proposed enlargement of the Community to include Austria, Sweden, Finland and Switzerland, for instance, will affect the character and concerns of the Union. Both these considerations require that the specific items for negotiation in the 1996 conference be decided upon closer to that date.
Ireland will play its part in shaping the agenda for the 1996 negotiations, in consultation with our Community partners.

As regards the development of a federal Europe, Ireland had no objection to the proposal during the negotiations to insert a reference to the “federal vocation” of the Union in Article B of the Treaty. In the event the Intergovernmental Conference decided not to include this provision.

If, as is likely, this issue is raised again in 1996, the Government will decide its negotiating position in the light of the circumstances applying then. However, it is very likely that it would be in Ireland's interest to continue to support a federal vocation for the European Union.
In due course, the Government will report to the Dáil on the prospects for the 1996 Intergovernmental Conferences and will keep the House informed of negotiations when they commence.

The Government will also consider an information campaign at the appropriate time — it is not possible at this stage to predict the character of the campaign in advance of the outcome of negotiations in 1996.

I would add that the Government mounted an extensive information campaign during the recent referendum. Apart from a series of factsheets on the Treaty, an extensive multi-media campaign, a Freefone information service and the provision of copies of the Treaty in public libraries and main post-offices nationwide, the campaign included the delivery of a Short Guide to the Maastricht Treaty to every home in the country — despite the postal dispute.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Non-Political Sanctions against Iraq.

Qst.Quest: if, in view of the hardship now being endured by the civilian population of Iraq, the Government will urge the lifting of all non-military sanctions against that country; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: The sanctions imposed on Iraq by the United Nations Security Council prevent imports from, and exports to, Iraq but they make exceptions in respect of foodstuffs, medicines and materials and supplies for other essential civilian needs.

Furthermore, the Security Council agree that Iraq could export petroleum products up to the value of 1.6 billion US dollars, the sum to be paid into an account administered by the Secretary General and to serve principally to finance the purchase of food, medicines and essential civilian needs. The Security Council has also provided that funds from other sources may be deposited in that account and be immediately available to meet the humanitarian needs of the Iraqi population.

The suffering of the Iraqi civilian population is a matter of great concern but it must be made clear that the responsibility for this situation lies with Saddam Hussein. The issue here is not one of availability of resources; Iraq is rich in oil resources. It is the persistent refusal of the Iraqi regime to comply in full with Security Council resolutions that has led to the hardships being endured by the civilian population.

MainHeading.P: In February, Saddam Hussein broke off negotiations with the United Nations which were intended to permit the sale of Iraqi oil to enable essential civilian needs in Iraq to be met. I am glad to say that those negotiations have resumed since then, and that the UN Secretary-General has said that Iraq is now taking a positive attitude as regards the implementation of UN resolutions although it has not yet implemented all of them.

I hope the Iraqi authorities will co-operate fully with the Security Council and will reach agreement with the UN on the sale of oil in order to ensure much-needed relief and assistance for the people of Iraq.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Indonesian Human Rights Abuses.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the fact that there is a proposed sale from British Aerospace to Indonesia of 40 Hawk fighter trainer aircraft for a consideration of £600 million; and whether he is going to make representations, particularly in light of Indonesia's action against East Timor's independence campaign and in view of their record of serious human rights abuses including genocide.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Arms Sales.

Qst.hpid: Mr. M. Higgins Mr. M. Higgins
Qst.Quest: if he will outline the Irish Government's position in general towards arms sales by members of the European Community to zones of conflict outside the Community; and if, in particular, the Irish Government will be expressing an opinion within the context of the European Community of the sale by the United Kingdom of 40 Hawk fighter trainer aircraft BAE to the Indonesian Government.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions No. 34 and No. 75 together.

MainHeading.P: Ireland is not a producer of arms but we have always advocated restraint in arms sales in the interests of international peace and stability.

In its Declaration on Non-Proliferation and Arms Exports of 29 June last year, the European Council identified a number of common criteria on which the national arms export policies of EC member states were based. Ireland fully supports these criteria which are in line with our national policy. These criteria are:

—respect for the international commitments of the Member States of the Community, in particular the sanctions decreed by the Security Council of the United Nations and those decreed by the Community, agreements on non-proliferation and other subjects, as well as other international obligations;
—the respect of human rights in the country of final destination;
—the internal situation in the country of final destination, as a function of the existence of tensions or internal armed conflict;
—the preservation of regional peace, security and stability;
—the national security of the member states and of territories whose external relations are the responsibility of a member state, as well as that of friendly and allied countries;
—the behaviour of the buyer country with regard to the International Community, as regards in particular its attitude to terrorism, the nature of its alliances, and respect for International Law;
—the existence of a risk that the equipment will be diverted within the buyer country or re-exported under undesirable conditions.
An eighth criterion relating to the technical and economic capacity of the importing countries to absorb the arms in question was adopted by the European Council in Lisbon on 26 and 27 June.

These criteria represent the first step in a process of developing a common policy among the Twelve towards arms exports as part of a broader policy of non-proliferation. For the present, it is a matter for each member state to interpret and apply the common criteria on a national basis.

I am aware of reports of a proposed sale to Indonesia of up to 40 Hawk fighter trainer aircraft by a British firm. It is a matter for the UK Government to ensure that the common criteria are respected in their national practices.

With regard to the human rights situation, Ireland and our Community partners have issued a number of statements over the past year condemning the serious human rights abuses that have taken place in East Timor. The Indonesian Government can be in no doubt as to how seriously we, and our Community partners, view the violation of human rights.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Oireachtas Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs.

Qst.Quest: if his Department has prepared draft terms of reference for the proposed Oireachtas Committee on Foreign Affairs; if he will publish the draft terms of reference; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: The Department of Foreign Affairs was involved in the preparation of draft terms of reference which were circulated some weeks ago by the Government Chief Whip and are currently under discussion among the parties. When the present round of informal consultations has been concluded the proposed terms of reference will be published in the form of a draft resolution which will be laid before both Houses of the Oireachtas. The approval of both Houses will be required for the establishment of the Committee.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the fact that at least 20 Palestinian detainees have died in Israeli custody during the past four years; if he has made, or plans to make, any representations to the Israeli authorities on this issue; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: I can assure the House that I am conscious of, and I deplore, the deaths of Palestinian detainees which have occurred in Israeli custody over the past four years. Ireland has joined with its European Community partners in making numerous representations to the Israeli authorities on this and on other human rights issues in the Occupied Territories. Ireland has also made representations bilaterally to the Israeli authorities concerning the situation of Palestinians in the Occupied Territories.

The illegal occupation of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip and the continuing abuses of human rights there are of grave concern to Ireland and our partners in the European Community. The Government attach great importance to the current Middle East peace process, in which we are participating both at national and European Community levels. That process offers the best prospects for reaching an overall Middle East settlement which would at last bring an end to the suffering of Palestinian civilians as well as meeting Israel's legitimate security requirements.

The Declaration of the European Council meeting in Lisbon on 26-27 June on the Middle East Peace Process restated the Community's position on the situation in the Occupied Territories and explicitly called on all parties to refrain from all acts of violence that are likely to jeopardise the Peace Process in any way.

That Declaration also expressed the belief that last month's election results in Israel will reinforce the Peace Process and called on the new Israeli Government to seize the opportunity to negotiate a comprehensive peace.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - New Soviet Republic Recognition.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline the number of the new republics that have come into existence from the dissolution of the Soviet Union to which this country has given recognition or established some form of diplomatic relations; and if he will make a statement on any effects on trade between this country and these republics as compared to the trading position we had with the old Soviet Union.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: All 11 members of the Commonwealth of Independent States have been formally recognised by Ireland. The Irish Ambassador in Moscow is accredited to the Russian Federation; non-resident diplomatic relations have been established with Belarus, Kazakhstan and Ukraine. The establishment of formal diplomatic relations with the remaining seven states will be considered from time to time in the light of our national and international interests and the availability of the necessary resources.

It is difficult to make a precise assessment of the likely effects on trade of the dissolution of the Soviet Union, particularly since separate statistics were not previously recorded on trade with the constituent republics. However, the bulk of our trade in the past was with the Russian Federation and this will probably continue to be the case. I am conscious that there are also considerable opportunities for doing business with the new republics, especially in the services sector, and these are being actively pursued.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Libyan Arms to IRA.

Qst.Quest: whether he intends to seek a meeting with the Libyan Government to obtain details of the arms, weapons, ammunition and explosives supplied by Libya to the IRA; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: While it would not be appropriate to comment on the detail of exchanges in the security area I can assure the House that the Libyan authorities are fully aware of the Government's condemnation of any assistance to groups engaged in terrorism and of the vital importance of recovering weapons and explosives which have previously been provided to the IRA.

In this connection the Deputy will be aware that representatives of the Libyan Government recently gave the British authorities certain information about the assistance which Libya has provided to the IRA.

I can confirm that these developments are being monitored closely, and I would like to assure the Deputy that the Government will continue to pursue the matter as appropriate and to take any further action as circumstances require.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline the facilities his Department provide for new ambassadors accredited to this country to brief them on current issues; if he has yet had an opportunity to meet the new United States Ambassador to Ireland; if his attention has been drawn to the criticisms of the appointment expressed in Irish-American newspapers; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: It is usual for newly arrived Ambassadors, once they have presented their credentials to the President, to call on the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Arrangements are also made by the Department of Foreign Affairs for all newly arrived Ambassadors to have meetings with the Secretary and other senior officials in the Department in the course of which they are briefed on issues of current interest. In addition, the Department provides to each incoming Ambassador a suggested list of persons in the political, economic, social and educational fields on whom calls might be made. Where there is a resident Embassy in Dublin, arrangements for such calls are normally made between the Embassy and the person concerned. In the case of non-resident Embassies, the Protocol Section of my Department will on request assist in arranging such calls.

In reply to the second part of the Deputy's question, I can confirm that I had a very positive and substantive meeting with the newly arrived United States Ambassador. Mr. William FitzGerald, on Monday, 29 June; I have every confidence that the excellent relations which exist between the US and Ireland will continue to flourish during Ambassador FitzGerald's assignment in Dublin.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Somalian Refugees.

Qst.Quest: if he will give details of the efforts and relief he has made available to the refugees of Somalia; and if he will raise the inhuman treatment of these refugees at EC and UN level.

whether the Government intend to provide any special aid for refugees in Somalia, in view of the continuing deprivation from drought and civil strife, as highlighted by the recent deaths of 140 refugees seeking to reach the Yemen; and if he will make a statement on the matter.
if, in view of the very serious famine in Somalia, he will sanction payment of a special amount of finance to the relevant agencies in charge of this area.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: I will take Questions Nos. 48, 71 and 291 together.

MainHeading.P: The Government are very concerned about the situation in Somalia which has developed into an appalling human disaster. Many thousands of people have died since the civil war broke out in 1991 and now there is the added problem of the drought. The number of displaced persons is estimated to be as high as 2 million.

The scale of the problem is so vast that it must be confronted at international level. It is heartening to note that, despite all the difficulties and dangers, the United Nations and other relief agencies, including Irish non-governmental organisations, are pressing ahead with the relief effort.

Ireland is playing its part in the effort to help the people of Somalia. A total of £125,000 has been provided from the Disaster Relief Fund to agencies involved there. Much of this aid has been directed at providing for the basic food and health needs of displaced persons and refugees who are surviving under dreadful conditions.

Ireland also participates in the EC emergency relief and long term aid programmes. The total value of EC assistance to Somalia so far is equivalent to over £24 million of which £10 million was allocated under the EC Special Food Aid Programme.

I was deeply concerned to hear about the recent tragic incident, in which refugees died when their ship went aground off the Yemen coast. Thousands more were stranded without food or water. On instruction, the Ambassador in Geneva raised this incident as a matter of urgency with the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. Ireland has also raised the matter with our partners in the European Community. I understand that assistance is being provided by the EC Commission, by some EC member states and the UNHCR.
I will continue to keep developments in Somalia under close review. I am committed to doing what I can to help alleviate the situation there, both at a political and a humanitarian level.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Departmental Reorganisation.

Qst.Quest: if he has any plans to reorganise his Department in the light of the European Union Treaty and the completion of the single market which will now convert previously foreign issues to domestic issues; if he will outline the precise organisational and administrative relationship between his Department and the Minister of State in the Taoiseach's Department with responsibility for European Affairs; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: As has been the position since Ireland joined the European Communities in 1973, the Minister for Foreign Affairs is responsible for the conduct of Ireland's relations within the Communities. The structure and organisation of the Department is kept under constant review to ensure that it continues to respond effectively to the needs of that role and the responsibilities arising from Ireland's membership of the Community and of the developing European Union.

The Treaty on European Union reinforces Community competence in some areas and introduces new competences in other areas. In this regard, however, the new Treaty goes no further than the Treaty of Accession or the Single European Act in converting foreign issues to domestic issues. Since Ireland joined the Community in 1973, Ministers have attended Council meetings in Brussels which take decisions in specific areas for which they have domestic responsibility and look after EC business within those areas of responsibility. For example, the Minister for Labour has attended meetings of the Social Affairs Council since Ireland joined the Community. That Council took on board the legislative consequences of the important advance in Community competence arising from the Single European Act and will take account of the consequences of the agreement on social policy annexed to the Maastricht Treaty.

MainHeading.P: Irish interests in the Community are drawn together through the exercise of co-ordination responsibilities by the Minister of State for European Affairs in the Department of the Taoiseach who presides over the interdepartmental European Co-ordination Committee. This committee responds, inter alia, to the role of the European Council in Community affairs and provides an integrated framework for the conduct of our Community relations.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - EC Membership Applications.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline (1) the countries which have applied for membership of the EC in one form or another and (2) the attitude of Ireland to these applications.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the fact that the Spanish Foreign Minister has indicated that Spain may withhold co-operation from enlarging the membership of the European Community unless there is an agreement to the early establishment of the Cohesion Fund; and whether Ireland supports this stand by Spain.

if he will outline the initiatives, if any, he has taken, to analyse and study the implications for Ireland of the enlargement of the European Community to embrace the EFTA countries; if he proposes any direct bilateral visits or meetings with himself, his officials and representatives of Sweden, Finland, Austria, Switzerland and Norway to ensure the best possible outcome of enlargement from Ireland's point of view; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: I propose to answer Questions Nos. 53, 59 and 65 together.

Seven applications for membership of the EC are currently outstanding. These are from Turkey, Austria, Malta, Cyprus, Sweden, Finland and Swizerland. There are indications that further applications may be made in the near future.

MainHeading.P: Ireland's general attitude to the question of enlargement is an open and positive one. The Treaty stipulates that any European state may apply to become a member. Our concern is that enlargement should he handled in such a way as not to diminish the momentum towards European integration. We would also wish to be certain that applicants are capable of taking on the obligations of membership. In determining this the formal opinion of the Commission, as required under Article 237 on each application, is of major importance.

With the growing number of applications it has been clear for some time that the enlargement issue would become an important one on the Community agenda. We therefore fully supported the decision taken at the Maastricht European Council in December last year to consider the issue in depth at the Lisbon European Council on the basis of a study by the Commission. The outcome of the decision at Lisbon has already been reported to the House in the statements made on 2 July.

My Department has begun the process of examining with other Departments the implications of the likely next round of enlargement for Ireland. In the case of the EFTA countries it should be noted that a considerable amount of ground relevant to accession has already been covered in the negotiations to establish between the EC and EFTA a European Economic Area. Analysis of the issues posed by the pending membership applications will be intensified in the period ahead as the Commission opinion on each application becomes available. Numerous meetings at official and ministerial level at which enlargement has been discussed have taken place in recent years with representatives of the EFTA member states. The Finnish Foreign Minister for example was in Dublin on 19 February. The Swedish royal visit in April was the occasion for valuable discussion with the Swedish Foreign Minister. I expect such contacts to continue and indeed intensify in coming months.

The timing of enlargement negotiations was considered by the Lisbon European Council. The conclusions state that official negotiations on accession would open only after the Maastricht Treaty is ratified and an agreement reached on the Delors II package. This reaffirms an agreement reached in Maastricht in December. Ireland firmly supported this line at the European Council as did Spain. Preparatory work is likely to be undertaken in coming months in line with the Council conclusions which aim at having the proposed general negotiation framework for enlargement ready for consideration at the next European Council in Edinburgh in December. As to the Cohesion Fund, the Deputy will be aware that it was agreed at Lisbon that it would be put in place early in 1993.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Waiver of American Visa Requirement.

Qst.Quest: if, having regard to the fact that British citizens do not require visas for entry to the United States, he will now open discussions with the American Government to waive the visa requirement in view of the harassment and treatment which Irish citizens are getting from the American Embassy in Dublin when they apply for visas.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: The Department of Foreign Affairs has been in contact with the US authorities since 1986 in the matter of waiving the visa requirement for Irish visitors to the US.

Section 313 of the US Immigration Reform and Control Act, 1986, provided for the establishment of a visa waiver pilot programme for visitors from certain countries to the US. Under the terms of the Act, the pilot programme can be introduced only in respect of countries which have a low rate of holiday and business visa refusals. Continuing qualification depends on a low overstay rate in the US on the part of those who benefit from the scheme. In implementing the scheme, the US authorities are giving priority to countries where there is a large volume of holiday and business visitors to the US.

MainHeading.P: The volume of visa applications from Ireland is small by comparison with those countries in respect of whom the visa waiver scheme is currently being implemented and this is a factor to be taken into account in assessing our prospects for inclusion in the scheme, at least in the short term. We are nevertheless continuing our discussions with the US authorities in the matter.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Kidnap of Nicaraguan Teachers.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the plight of a number of Nicaraguan literacy teachers who were kidnapped by Contra forces in 1984 and who are reported to be still illegally detained in Honduras; if he will urge the Government of Honduras to ensure their release; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: Many kidnappings are reported to have taken place during the conflict in Nicaragua.
There is in Nicaragua a Commission on Human Rights which is looking into all reported cases of people who disappeared during the conflict in that country.
In addition, the UN Commission on Human Rights is investigating all the reported cases of kidnappings and where appropriate is in contact with the Honduran authorities in the matter.

The two bodies I have mentioned are aware of reports of kidnapping of literacy teachers in 1984. Amnesty International are also investigating cases of kidnapping in Nicaragua and, I understand, are currently trying to substantiate reports which they have received of kidnapping of literacy teachers in 1984.
I remain deeply concerned about unresolved cases of disappearances which occurred during the conflict in Nicaragua. I will continue to follow the situation closely.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Overseas Development Assistance.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline the extent to which Ireland's contribution to overseas development aid is keeping pace with the contribution for other developed countries; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

if, in the light of statements by him and the Taoiseach after the Rio de Janeiro Conference generally committing this country to a contribution of overseas development aid closer to the United Nations target, he will give details of the exact figures meant by these promises.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. O'Keeffe Mr. J. O'Keeffe
Qst.Quest: whether he intends to introduce a supplementary estimate to increase Ireland's overseas aid programme.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: I propose to answer Questions Nos. 56, 61 and 282 together.
It is estimated that total ODA for 1992 will amount to £42.9 million which would represent 0.17 per cent of Gross National Product — GNP.

I am making available a tabular statement of the 1991 ODA contributions of those developed countries which are members of the OECD Development Assistance Committee. The figures for 1992 are not yet available. Ireland is at the bottom of the list for 1991. Clearly this is a matter for regret. It is Government policy to continue to do what it can to help to relieve the crisis confronting the developing countries and to provide long term assistance through the ODA programme. The revised Programme for Government includes a commitment that the Government will undertake a planned programme of increases in Ireland's Official Overseas Development Assistance 1992-1994, so as to achieve a higher ODA/GNP contribution by the end of that period. I am anxious that we should make steady progress towards improving our performance.

MainHeading.P: At the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro Ireland agreed to participate in a European Community initiative to establish a start-up fund to address the problem of poverty reduction and the building of management skills in developing countries. The financial implications for Ireland have yet to be fully quantified. I intend to discuss with the Minister for Finance how we can meet our commitments.

Qst.hpid: Mr. G. O'Sullivan Mr. G. O'Sullivan
Qst.Quest: if he will outline the action, if any, he has taken with the British authorities regarding the recent incursion of British troops across the Border.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. O'Keeffe Mr. J. O'Keeffe
Qst.Quest: whether he has received a response from the United Kingdom authorities in relation to the incursion by the British army outside Clones, County Monaghan; if so, if he will outline the explanation given; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 58 and 296 together.

MainHeading.P: The incursion to which the Deputies refer occurred on 20 June 1992 in the area of Derrybeg, Drumully, County Monaghan. The Government take a serious view of such incidents and the matter was immediately raised with the British authorities.
The British authorities have admitted that their troops crossed the Border and they have apologised for this incursion which they state was accidental and due to a map reading error.
While I welcome this prompt acknowledgement and apology it remains the case that incidents of this nature continue to give rise to disquiet and concern in Border areas.
I will continue to impress on the British authorities the seriousness with which the Government view such incidents.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Middle East Peace Talks Prospects.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline his assessment of the prospects for the peace talks in the Middle East in the light of the outcome of the Israeli general election; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: I very much hope that the prospects for the peace talks in the Middle East will improve as a result of the Israeli election. It is most important that the peace talks, which were launched last autumn, should make real progress. I believe we can now look forward with greater confidence to progress being made in the peace talks in the months ahead.

The European Council in Lisbon on 26-27 June stated its belief that the election results will reinforce the peace process and reiterated the need for all parties to commit themselves to the process and to seize the opportunity to negotiate a comprehensive peace.

The European Council expressed the hope that the new Israeli Government and the Arab parties will act quickly to implement confidence building measures. The European Council looked forward to a halt to settlements in the occupied territories, including East Jerusalem, and to full application of the terms of the Fourth Geneva Convention. It also called on the members of the Arab League to lift the trade boycott of Israel.

MainHeading.P: I believe that the measures set out by the European Council would contribute greatly to creating a climate of confidence between the parties concerned.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Irish Embassy for Hungary.

Qst.Quest: if, in view of the presence in Dublin of an active Hungarian Embassy and the need to consolidate and develop political and cultural links as well as the growing trade links between Ireland and Hungary in the light of Hungary's declared intentions to be a full member of the European Community in the year 2000, he intends to seek to have a full Irish Embassy opened in Budapest by absorbing the existing Irish office there belonging to An Bord Tráchtála and obtaining the necessary additional finances from within the overall Government estimates from the moneys assigned to both ABT and the IDA; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: I appreciate the importance of Hungary, a country with which Ireland has had diplomatic relations since 1974. The Irish Ambassador to Austria is accredited on a non-residential basis to Hungary. We welcomed the establishment of a resident Hungarian Embassy in Dublin in 1990.

MainHeading.P: My Department are continuing to develop Ireland's political, cultural and economic links with Hungary. However, our network of resident diplomatic missions is small and must remain so for the foreseeable future, given our limited financial and personnel resources. We do, of course, keep the possibility of extension of the network under review in the light of our changing national and international interests and the resources available to us, including any possibilities for redeployment of resources. As a general matter, however, it would not be possible for me to speak publicly in advance about proposals, if any, which might be under consideration at any particular time in relation to the establishment of an embassy in any particular country, since decisions in these matters have to be agreed in each case with the foreign Government concerned and could be announced only in consultation with it.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the initiative by the Norwegian Government seeking a ban on the underground testing of nuclear weapons; if, in the light of the underground test carried out by the United States on 23 June, the Government will publicly support the Norwegian initiative; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: I am aware that the Norwegian Foreign Minister has written to his counterparts in the United States, China and the United Kingdom to the effect that there is no longer any need for nuclear testing and that the time is now ripe for making progress towards the goal of a comprehensive ban on the testing of nuclear weapons.

The Government strongly support the views of the Norwegian Foreign Minister which coincide with the policy which successive Irish Governments have adopted on this issue over the years. The Government welcome the fact that Russia and France have temporarily suspended their nuclear testing programmes and would urge the other nuclear powers to follow their example.
Ireland has long been a supporter of a comprehensive ban on nuclear testing. The Government continue to believe that such a ban is essential to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Ministerial Visit to Iran.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline the discussions he engaged in during his visit to Iran between 3 and 5 March 1992 with regard to the Iranian Government's opposition to the Middle East peace process.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: When I visited Iran at the beginning of March, the Iranian Foreign Minister, Dr. Ali Akbar Velayati, and I had a thorough exchange of views on a range of issues, including the Middle East Peace Process. Dr. Velayati stated Iran's well-known opposition to the current peace talks, believing that they would not be successful. I expressed Ireland's strong commitment to the peace process and urged that the negotiations should be given every opportunity to produce results. Those negotiations are taking place both at bilateral and multilateral level. The bilateral talks are being pursued by Israel and its Arab neighbours. The multilateral talks include the Middle East parties and a number of non-regional participants including Ireland and the other member states of the European Community.

Qst.Quest: if he has made any protest to the Bangladeshi Government over the massacre of 1,200 tribal people by government troops and settlers in the Chittagong Hill Tracts on 10 April 1992; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: I am aware of reports of a massacre of tribal people at a village in the Chittagong Hill Tracts of Bangladesh on 10 April 1992. There are conflicting accounts of the number of people killed in the incident; the Bangladeshi authorities state the 12 people were killed while human rights organisations claim that there were several hundred victims.

The Government of Bangladesh have established an official inquiry, under a retired judge, into the reported massacre. The aim of the inquiry is to establish the facts and make recommendations to the Government.

While remaining deeply concerned at human rights abuses wherever they occur, Ireland and our partners in the European Community, will await the outcome of this inquiry before considering any action in the matter.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Israeli Embassy for Dublin.

Qst.Quest: if, in the interests of promoting peace in the Middle East, safeguarding the lives of Irish personnel serving there with the United Nations and developing deeper and better relations between Ireland and Israel, the Government will agree to Israel's repeated requests for permission for Israel to open a residential embassy in Dublin, without requiring a reciprocal opening in Israel by Ireland of an Irish Embassy, in view of the presence in Dublin of Arab embassies and the fact that Dublin is the only EC capital that has denied Israel its request to open an embassy; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: Ireland and Israel maintain diplomatic relations at ambassadorial level on a non-residential basis.

The question of the establishment of resident embassies is a matter for discussion between the two Governments concerned and it would be inappropriate for me to comment publicly on discussions with the Israeli Government.

(iii) Environmental Adviser on matters relating to environmental issues.
(iv) Special Communications Adviser on media related matters.
(v) Special Economic Development Officer who advises on projects to advance national or local economic development.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. O'Malley) Desmond J. O'Malley
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. O'Malley)
Speaker.P: It is assumed that the Deputy's question refers to laboratory tests carried out on products in relation to compliance with product safety regulations. The purpose behind such tests is not always to secure prosecution, but rather to ensure compliance with the relevant regulations.
