MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Stamp Duty on House Sales.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Qst.Quest: the approximate cost to the Exchequer of the proposal referred to by An Taoiseach in his reply to a parliamentary question on 3 June 1992 to raise the exemption from stamp duty for the sale of houses from 125 square metres to 140 square metres; and the reason this proposal was not accepted.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. B. Ahern) Bertie Ahern
Speaker.P: While it is difficult to estimate the year-to-year loss of revenue that would have resulted from the implementation of the proposal, figures available for the number of new houses in this category built in 1991 suggest that the revenue loss from increasing the exemption could have been in the region of £1.5 million. It is claimed that this significant surrender of revenue by the Exchequer would be offset by a reduction in the number of unemployed. However, the likely effects of the proposed change have been analysed within the constraints of my Department's model of the Irish economy. The results of this simulation indicate that the overall impact of the measures would be negative, because the direct loss of tax revenue would exceed the marginal benefits arising from a very insignificant increase in employment.

The proposal would also have been contrary to the overall spirit of recommendations made by such bodies as the Commission on Taxation, the OECD, the IMF and the Culliton report against this country's over-reliance on the use of tax reliefs as a mechanism to stimulate economic activity. The Culliton report particularly advised against a diversion of savings into areas such as high quality residential construction.

Finally, I consider that there are strong reasons of equity for not proceeding with the proposal. All second-hand houses, small or medium-sized or large, are subject to stamp duty on sale. It would be inequitable to raise the existing stamp duty exemption threshold to include even bigger new houses, almost certainly being bought by people with an above-average income, while small second-houses being bought by low-income and medium-income purchasers of second-hand houses continued to be subject to stamp duty.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Purchasing Procedures.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline the standard Government purchasing procedures which are prescribed by his Department for the purchase of computer equipment by Government Departments.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. B. Ahern) Bertie Ahern
Speaker.P: Purchasing procedures for computer equipment in Government Departments are an extension of the purchasing procedures that apply to the procurement of goods and services in general by Government Departments. These general procedures are set out in “An outline of Government Contracts Procedures” published by the Stationery Office (PI 4120).

Most Government Departments now have a formal information technology, IT, plan which sets out how computer systems can assist a Department to meet its objectives and provide the overall framework within which purchases of specific items of computer equipment for each Department are made. In many instances these plans outline the major technical characteristics of the hardware and software to be used in the Department in question. Wherever possible, the aim is to choose a technical direction which allows for the competitive purchasing of computer equipment and services. When a Department has established the need for additional equipment in line with its information technology plan it prepares a formal request for proposals setting out the requirement in as much detail as possible and seeks competitive tenders for the supply of the equipment. In some instances regrettably it is not possible to get competitive tenders, usually because of the necessity to purchase equipment which is compatible with equipment already installed in a particular site.

MainHeading.P: Under the administrative budget initiative Departments then purchase computer equipment and services without further reference to the Department of Finance subject to the following conditions: that the purchase is in accord with an approved information technology plan, that it has been possible to get two or more competitive tenders, that the procedures set out in “An Outline of Government Contracts Procedures” have been complied with and that various EC requirements including the advertisement in the Official Journal of all proposed contracts in excess of 130,000 ECU have been met.
Where these conditions cannot be met a Department must seek the specific sanction of the Minister for Finance before undertaking the proposed expenditure.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Motor Vehicle Taxation.

Qst.Quest: if he will make a statement on the changes in taxation of motor vehicles from 1 January 1993 and the effect these changes will have on vehicle prices.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. B. Ahern) Bertie Ahern
Speaker.P: Under the rules agreed for the post-1992 VAT regime, new motor vehicles will be liable to VAT in the country of destination i.e. where they are used in all cases, regardless of where purchased within the Community. In so far as used vehicles are concerned, the application of VAT will depend on the precise circumstances of the transaction. For private individuals resident in the State, purchasing used vehicles from a dealer in another member state, VAT will be payable only in the country of purchase. Where the purchase is from a private individual in another member state, the question of VAT will not arise. Detailed rules remain to be worked out for purchases of used vehicles by dealers in one member state from dealers or private individuals in another Community country. Discussions on this particular aspect are actively underway in Brussels.

MainHeading.P: The existing initial excise duty on motor vehicles will be replaced by a first registration charge, as I announced in my budget speech. This new charge, which is designed to comply with EC Single Market requirements, will be aimed at producing broadly equivalent revenue and will take effect from 1 January 1993. The main legislative framework for the new vehicle registration tax is contained in Chapter IV of the Finance Act, 1992, sections 130 to 144. Further detailed provisions will be made by way of regulations, as provided for in that Act, in the coming months, while the rates of tax to apply will be set out in the autumn Finance Bill. It is my intention when setting the actual rates that these revised taxation arrangements will leave the cost of vehicles to motorists largely unchanged.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline the current EC proposals on the harmonisation of VAT on energy; and if he will make a statement on Government policy in this area.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. B. Ahern) Bertie Ahern
Speaker.P: Under the terms of outline agreements reached in June 1991 by the EC Council of Ministers in regard to the coverage and rates of VAT to apply after 1992 when the Single Market is completed, energy products generally are intended to be liable to the standard VAT rate.

However, member states will have the option of applying a reduced VAT rate to supplies of natural gas and electricity provided that, in the view of the EC Commission, such reduced rating would not lead to distortions of competition. Furthermore, special provision has been made for Ireland to reflect the position that the UK will be entitled to retain zero-rating of energy products for heating and lighting. In the event that this situation gives rise to distortions of competition we may have the option, on foot of authorisation by the Commission, to apply a reduced rate to such supplies generally. The agreement reached, which it is intended will be enshrined in a directive, also includes certain provisions in relation to products to which member states have applied reduced rates but where the option will not be available in the future. At present, the 12½ per cent rate of VAT applies here to energy products for heating, lighting and power. This would qualify as a reduced rate after 1992. The actual VAT rates to apply to energy products as to other goods and services in the future will, of course, fall to be determined in the light of overall budgetary, economic and competitive considerations.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Carbon Dioxide Emissions.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline the tonnage of carbon dioxide which was emitted by power stations in 1990; and whether he has any plans to stabilise or reduce carbon dioxide emissions from the 1990 levels; and if so, when.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Energy (Mr. Molloy) Robert Molloy
Speaker.P: The level of carbon dioxide emitted by power stations in 1990 was 10.9 million tonnes.

The EC is committed to stabilising CO 2, emissions in the Community as a whole at 1990 levels by the year 2000. This commitment was made at the joint Energy and Environment Council in Luxembourg in 1990 and reaffirmed in December 1991.

The Department of the Environment in consultation with my Department and other relevant Departments in preparing a national carbon dioxide abatement strategy for the Government's consideration prior to submission to the EC Commission. This strategy will make appropriate allowance for growth in Ireland's CO 2 emissions, reflecting circumstances in our economic development which are different from the more mature economies of many other EC member states.

MainHeading.P: Ireland still has an open mind on the approach to be adopted by the Commission to achieve limitation of CO 2 emissions by year 2000. However, we consider that much greater analysis of the proposal is needed both at Community and member states level before any informed decision is made on the matter.

Qst.Quest: if he has any proposals to review and revise the way in which replies to parliamentary questions are prepared and finalised within his Department in order to ensure accuracy, clarity and democratic accountability in view of the concerns recently expressed about the inadequacy of parliamentary replies; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: In reply to Question No. 29 in the House from the Deputy on 7 April 1992, I indicated that throughout my career as a Minister and public representative I have always been committed to a policy of openness and transparency. I went on to indicate a number of the means by which I had put that policy into effect since becoming Minister for the Marine.

I am not aware of any concerns expressed about the adequacy of the replies to parliamentary questions put down to the Minister for the Marine and I cannot accept the premise implicit in the Deputy's question that there is any deficiency in replies which I give to this House in the areas of “accuracy, clarity or democratic accountability” or indeed any other areas and I think that an objective assessment would bear that out.

Every effort is made in preparing such replies to ensure that the objectives mentioned by the Deputy are met. My Department has established a most rigorous and thorough going system for dealing with parliamentary questions which are accorded the highest priority of all business dealt with within my Department. The system for preparing these replies is kept under continuous review.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline (1) the number of special policy advisers in his and his Minister of State's Departments and (2) their respective area of expertise.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: There are no special policy advisers responsible to me or to the Minister of State at my Department.

Qst.Quest: his views on whether there has been undue delay in the processing of the case regarding the illegal reclamation of foreshore at Mornington, County Meath; if he agrees that the reason this has continued is because of the lack of response to a volume of representation from the Drogheda Harbour Commissioners; if his attention has been drawn to the fact that, under the terms of the 1933 Foreshore Act, his Department will be responsible for any deterioration in the navigable channel arising from the illegal reclamation of the foreshore due to the total lack of response by his Department; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: The case raised by the Deputy is an extremely complex one, involving allegations of illegal reclamation of the State foreshore, claims regarding the impact of such reclamation on the navigable channel, and an application by Drogheda Harbour Commissioners for a foreshore lease to include the area of foreshore in question. Consideration of this case is at an advanced stage and it is hoped to bring the matter towards finality in the near future.

Qst.Quest: if, consequent, on the recent High Court decision relating to licences for fish farm development at Ballyvaughan, County Clare, he will outline the position of fish farming licences granted in the area of the Kenmare river in County Kerry which were under the same legislation.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: There is no change in the position of these licences.

Qst.Quest: the up-to-date position regarding funding for coastal erosion at Rosslare, County Wexford.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: My Department undertook coast protection works at Rosslare Strand last year, involving the construction of six new rock groynes. The programme for 1992 is for four new rock groynes. The contract for this work has been placed recently. Jointly funded by the Department of the Marine, 60 per cent and Wexford County Council, 40 per cent, these works will provide extra protection for the valuable tourist infrastructure and amenities at Rosslare Strand. Maintenance of the existing coast protection works is continuing.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Parliamentary Questions.

Qst.Quest: if he has any proposals to review and revise the way in which replies to parliamentary questions are prepared and finalised within his Department in order to ensure accuracy, clarity and democratic accountability in view of the concerns recently expressed about the inadequacy of parliamentary replies; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Flynn) Pádraig Flynn
Speaker.P: I have always been and remain conscious of my obligations as a Member of the Government to keep this House informed, via the mechanism of parliamentary questions, on matters within my area of responsibility which are of concern to Members of the House.

MainHeading.P: I am not aware of any concern about the adequacy of my replies to parliamentary questions, but if any Member is concerned about the adequacy of any particular reply on any subject, I will be glad to ensure that as much information as possible will be provided.

Qst.Quest: if, in view of the situation that currently exists in Milford Garda Barracks, County Donegal (details supplied) he will outline the steps he proposes to take to alleviate the situation immediately.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Flynn) Pádraig Flynn
Speaker.P: The Milford District headquarters building has structural problems which rule out refurbishment as an option. It is proposed instead to demolish the existing station and to build a new station on the site. Plans have been drawn up for this project. The station party will be housed in temporary accommodation while the new station is being built. It is not possible to say when work will commence — this will be determined in the light of overall priorities and available funds — but I can assure the Deputy that there will be no avoidable delay.

Qst.Quest: if he will give details of funds received by the State in each of the years 1980 to 1991 by way of stamp duties on court certificates or taxation following the taxation of legal costs by (a) the taxing masters of the High Court and (b) county registrars in each Circuit Court area; and if he will outline the amount of funds in each case received in respect of the taxation of family and matrimonial cases.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Flynn) Pádraig Flynn
Speaker.P: The information requested by the Deputy is not readily available and could be compiled only by the diversion to the task of a disproportionate amount of staff time, which could not be justified.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline (1) the number of special policy advisers in his and his Minister of State's Departments and (2) their respective area of expertise.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Flynn) Pádraig Flynn
Speaker.P: My Department have one special adviser who advises the Minister of State on policy matters.

Qst.Quest: if he has received complaints from a person (details supplied) in Dublin 7 regarding his imprisonment and treatment while in prison; and if he has investigated these complaints.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Flynn) Pádraig Flynn
Speaker.P: The question appears to relate to a person with a different address who was committed to Mountjoy Prison on 10 February 1992 to serve four days for contempt of court. He has made a rash of allegations to the European Commission on Human Rights regarding the treatment of other persons in Mountjoy Prison which I am satisfied are quite without foundation.

Qst.Quest: the way in which he proposes to expand community policing numbers in Leixlip, County Kildare, in view of the decision taken at the recent GRA Conference to object to and oppose the scheme until a suitable increase in manpower and resources takes place; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Flynn) Pádraig Flynn
Speaker.P: It is assumed that in the latter part of the question the Deputy is referring to the community policing initiative for rural areas, which was introduced in September 1991. The Garda authorities inform me that Leixlip, which is policed from Lucan Garda station, forms part of the Dublin Metropolitan Area and is not affected in any way by that initiative.

The Garda authorities also inform me that on 6 July an additional garda was assigned to Lucan station. This has enabled the Garda authorities to assign an additional community garda to Leixlip bringing the total number of community gardaí assigned to Leixlip to four. These gardaí are supported by foot and mobile patrols which are also provided from Lucan Garda station. The Garda authorities are satisfied that these arrangements meet the policing needs of the Leixlip area.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Garda Aptitude Test.

Qst.Quest: if there are any applicants who have failed aptitude tests in respect of their application for the Garda Síochána and who were then subsequently called for interview; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Flynn) Pádraig Flynn
Speaker.P: The Civil Service Commission are responsible for the conduct of competitions for the recruitment of Garda trainees and the Deputy will appreciate that I have no function in the matter.

I am informed by the Civil Service Commissioners that candidates for the Garda Síochána from the 1991 competition are being called to interview strictly in accordance with their performance in the written test. This means that only those candidates placed highest in the written test are being called to interview by the Civil Service Commission.

MainHeading.P: Perhaps the Deputy may be referring to the fact that some of the candidates who were initially notified that they were not among those being called to interview have subsequently been called. This is because the final number of candidates to be called for interview cannot be determined at the outset. Depending on the number of successful candidates following each round of interviews, it may be necessary to call further candidates until the required number of trainees has been achieved. There is no question of any candidate not having reached the required standard in the written test being called to interview.

Qst.Quest: if his Department have received a request for assistance to set up a residential centre (details supplied); and if he will outline his response to this request.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Flynn) Pádraig Flynn
Speaker.P: I have received a request from The Lillie Road Centre Ltd. for assistance to open a house to accommodate adolescent boys needing residential care. I understand that a similar approach has been made to the Ministers for Education and Health.
My Department's probation and welfare service have met with the director of the centre to discuss the proposal and follow-up discussions are planned to explore the matter further.
My Department will also be liaising with other Departments involved in this proposal.

Qst.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Qst.Quest: if he will have arrangements made to have a community garda appointed to the following neighbourhoods in Limerick city (1) Castletroy View (2) Linwood Park (3) Norwood Park, (4) Granville Park (5) Garryowen and (6) the Dublin Road; and if he will make a statement on the Government's policy relating to the appointment of community guards.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Flynn) Pádraig Flynn
Speaker.P: The allocation of Garda manpower, including the appointment of community gardaí, to individual areas is a matter for the Garda authorities. They inform me that there is already a full-time garda assigned to community policing duties in Castletroy View, which takes in the Dublin Road area. There is also a community garda assigned to the Garryowen area on a part-time basis. The question of assigning community gardaí to the other areas mentioned is being kept under consideration by the Garda authorities in the light of the overall policing needs of the division.

Qst.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Qst.Quest: if he will outline (1) the financial resources which were spent on refurbishing the Garda officers' accommodation at the Garda headquarters for 1991 and (2) the level of moneys which it is planned to spend on this in 1992.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Flynn) Pádraig Flynn
Speaker.P: A total of £32,753 was spent on works at the Garda officers' accommodation, Garda Headquarters, during 1991. This work involved rewiring, refurbishment, painting and decorating. To date no works have been carried out in 1992. The situation will be kept under review having regard to the need for new works, overall priorities and available funds.

Qst.Quest: the reason for the delay in the issuing of a land certificate by the Land Registry to a person (details supplied) in County Waterford; if he will ensure that this issues immediately as a bank refund is pending the issue of this.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Flynn) Pádraig Flynn
Speaker.P: I am informed by the Registrar of Titles that the application in question was lodged in the Land Registry in April and that the land certificate issued last week.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Suspension of Extradition Proceedings.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline the reason extradition proceedings in the case of a person (details supplied) in County Roscommon were suspended despite serious allegations of fraud in this case; and if he will confirm that the Fraud Squad investigations in this case have been closed; and the reason therefor.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Flynn) Pádraig Flynn
Speaker.P: It is not the practice for Ministers for Justice to make statements to the House about individual Garda investigations except in singular instances where the circumstances are so exceptional that such a course is deemed appropriate. I do not propose to depart from that practice on this occasion. As regards the question of extradition proceedings in this case, I would refer the Deputy to my reply to Question No. 133 on 4 February 1992.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline the levels of crime for the following areas in County Limerick: (1) Newcastle West, (2) Askeaton and (3) Bruff in each of the years 1989 to 1991; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Flynn) Pádraig Flynn
Speaker.P: I am informed by the Garda authorities that the number of indictable crimes recorded for the Garda districts referred to by the Deputy for the years 1989 and 1990 are as set out in the following tabular statement. Figures for 1991 are not yet available.

Qst.Quest: the total overhead costs expended on each law centre operated by the Legal Aid Board during 1991; and if he will make a statement on the matter.
the total overhead costs expended on each part-time law centre operated by the Legal Aid Board during the course of 1991; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Flynn) Pádraig Flynn
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 152 and 156 together.

The costs incurred by the board in providing legal services are given in the annual accounts of the Legal Aid Board which are laid before each House of the Oireachtas. I am informed by the board that it would not be possible to break down the overhead costs by law centre or part-time law centre without the expenditure of a disproportionate amount of staff time to the task.
The board have recently submitted to me their annual accounts for the year 1990, a copy of which will be laid before each House of the Oireachtas in due course.

Qst.Quest: the cost of the acquisition of the premises to house the law centre in Castlebar, County Mayo; and if he will make a statement on the matter.
the cost of the acquisition of the premises to house the law centre in Dundalk, County Louth; and if he will make a statement on the matter.
the cost of the acquisition of the premises to house the law centre in Letterkenny, County Donegal; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Flynn) Pádraig Flynn
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 153, 154 and 155 together.

The premises for the new law centres in Castlebar, Dundalk and Letterkenny are being leased — the rent payable being a current cost in the years in which it is payable. I am advised by the board that the only direct acquisition costs incurred by the board on two of the centres were on professional fees, amounting to £4,995 in the case of Castlebar and £6,937 in the case of Dundalk. In the case of Letterkenny the board incurred refurbishment costs of £18,000 in addition to professional fees of £4,970.

Qst.Quest: the number of solicitors employed by the Legal Aid Board on (1) 31 December 1990 (2) 20 June 1991 (3) 31 December 1991 and (4) 31 May 1992; the number of solicitors employed to operate the new law centres at (a) Castlebar, County Mayo (b) Dundalk, County Louth and (c) Letterkenny, County Donegal; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Flynn) Pádraig Flynn
Speaker.P: The number of solicitors employed by the Legal Aid Board on the dates referred to by the Deputy in his question was 33, 31, 37 and 39 respectively.
Each of the new law centres at Castlebar, Dundalk and Letterkenny is a one-solicitor centre.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Garda Barracks' Refurbishment.

Qst.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Qst.Quest: if he will outline the number of Garda barracks which he has planned to commence refurbishing in 1992.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Flynn) Pádraig Flynn
Speaker.P: The improvement of Garda accommodation is tackled on an ongoing basis. The work involved ranges from the provision of new stations to the provision of extensions, major refurbishment and minor decoration. The order in which stations are addressed is based on priorities established in consultation with the Garda authorities.

MainHeading.P: Five new stations have been completed since the beginning of 1992 and a further two are due to be completed before the end of the year. Extensions, refurbishment and minor new works have been carried out at a number of other centres. In addition, a major programme of maintenance work is being carried out to stations all over the country. It is not possible to say at this stage the total number of projects which will have commenced before the end of the year, but the maximum amount of work will be done, having regard to available finance and overall priorities.

Qst.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Qst.Quest: if he will outline the amount of money which he has allocated for the continued refurbishment of Templemore Training Centre in County Tipperary.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Flynn) Pádraig Flynn
Speaker.P: The only area where modernisation work is still required at the Garda Training College is in relation to physical education facilities. This is a very important aspect of police training and one to which I am strongly committed. As the Deputy will appreciate, however, funding for it has to be assessed in the context of overall resources and Garda accommodation needs generally. This matter is receiving active consideration in my Department at present.

Qst.hpid: Mr. V. Brady Mr. V. Brady
Qst.Quest: his views on whether road traffic laws are being breached by motorists carrying CD plates; and if any action is being considered by his Department to meet the problem.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Flynn) Pádraig Flynn
Speaker.P: I understand from the Garda authorities that they are not aware of any particular problem with regard to breaches of the road traffic acts by vehicles bearing CD plates.

Qst.Quest: if he has any plans to bring forward a juvenile justice Bill; if so, if he will outline the current status of such proposals; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Flynn) Pádraig Flynn
Speaker.P: Work is proceeding in my Department on a juvenile justice Bill which will replace the Children Act, 1908. It is my intention to have the appropriate legislation introduced as soon as possible but it is not possible for me at present to give a precise indication as to when the Bill will be ready.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: whether he has examined the proposal for a building extension at a school (details supplied) in Dublin 9; if he will outline the priority he has assigned to this long awaited project; and when this project will be allowed to proceed, if spending on such projects proceed at their present pace.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.P: The proposals in question, which involved the purchase of an adjacent premises, is no longer viable as the building has changed hands. The accommodation requirements of this school generally are now being reviewed by my Department.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the fact that (1) as a result of a reduction in teacher allocation for the coming academic year, a school (details supplied) in County Wexford will be unable to maintain the secretarial studies course which it has provided over many years and which is the only post-leaving certificate course provided at that school and (2) there is no alternative equivalent course available in this school's catchment area; if he will take steps to ensure that the teacher allocation necessary to maintain this course is sanctioned having regard to the fact that students of the course have been extremely successful in securing employment; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.P: The current staffing allocation for this school is 4.7 whole-time teacher equivalents in excess of what is normally allowed for a school of similar enrolment. The school is seeking a further allocation in addition to this.
My Department is currently examining the matter and will convey its decision shortly.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Higher Education Maintenance Grants.

Qst.Quest: if he has any plans to extend higher education maintenance grants to students from this jurisdiction attending university in other EC countries; whether this is common practice in the other 11 member countries of the EC; whether the withholding of these grants after the union has been formed will constitute a breach of students' rights; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.P: I have no plans to extend the provisions of the higher education grants scheme to cover students from this jurisdiction who are attending university in other EC member states.

The regulations governing grants in other EC states are a matter for each of the member states themselves. I understand that the matter of allowing students to retain grants while studying outside their own countries varies between the different member states.

There is no provision in existing EC legislation obliging member states to pay grants to students studying outside their own jurisdiction, and I am not aware of any proposals for legislation in this regard.

Qst.Quest: if it is the current policy of his Department to give grant aid to primary schools who are seeking funding for the construction of a general purpose room where none exists in the school; and, if so, if he will outline the rates which usually apply.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.P: It is my Department's policy to concentrate capital resources for national schools on essential classroom accommodation. It is not possible at the present time, within the resources available, to grant-aid general purpose rooms.

Qst.Quest: if he has any proposals to review and revise the way in which replies to parliamentary questions are prepared and finalised within his Department in order to ensure accuracy, clarity and democratic accountability in view of the concerns recently expressed about the inadequacy of parliamentary replies; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.P: My approach to parliamentary questions is that replies should be accurate and clear.
I can assure the Deputy that I will be continuing with this approach.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 168, 172, 185, 186, 193, 194, 201, 202, 203 and 204.

The information requested by the Deputies in relation to the numbers of one, two three and four teacher schools in various counties is given in the following table. Details regarding such schools are not available on a constituency basis.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Offaly School Renovation.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to an application to renovate a school (details supplied) in County Offaly by way of converting an existing assembly hall and kitchen to accommodate two extra classrooms; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.P: I am aware of the situation at the national school in County Offaly, referred to by the Deputy. My Department have already approved grant-aid towards the cost of the necessary alterations to provide extra accommodation, and the school authorities have been notified of the decision.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline the current situation as regards The Royal and Prior School, Raphoe, County Donegal (details supplied).

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.P: Architectural planning to provide additional accommodation at the school in question has been completed.

However, having regard to the capital resources available and my Department's ongoing commitments and priorities, I am not in a position to say when the project will be advanced beyond the current stage.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline (1) the number of special policy advisers in his and his Minister of State's Departments and (2) their respective area of expertise.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.P: Mr. Dick Doyle has been appointed as special adviser to the Minister for Education. His background and experience are in a wide range of governmental areas and he provides advice to me on a variety of policy matters.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline the works which have been approved by him and the costing thereof in respect of renovations for Mountmellick community school, County Laois; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.P: The works referred to by the Deputy are principally roof repairs and mechanical-electrical upgrading. The work is due to commence on 6 July 1992 at a cost of almost £400,000.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Appointment of Remedial Teacher.

Qst.Quest: if he has received an application from interested parties representing primary schools in Durrow, Cullahill, Ballacollagh and Clogh area of County Laois recommending the appointment of a remedial teacher; and if, having regard to the need for such a facility approval, it will be granted without delay.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.P: I have received a request for a remedial teacher from schools in the area in question.

As the Deputy will be aware, 80 additional remedial posts serving over 240 schools were allocated in the current school year as part of a national distribution under the Programme for Economic and Social Progress. These appointments were made following the collection of data and information by my Department's primary inspectorate from schools. The posts were then allocated on the basis of priority of need, as indicated by the information collected by the inspectorate.
The needs of other schools, including the schools mentioned by the Deputy, will be kept under review.

Qst.Quest: if he has figures for the numbers of leaving certificate students who were unable to take all, or part of their leaving certificate examination in 1991 and 1992 because of unexpected illness; his views on whether it is fair that such students have to wait for the following year to complete their examinations; if he will outline his views on whether there is a need to put in place a procedure whereby a student missing a subject or subjects through illness on the appointed examination day would have the opportunity of sitting the exam on another date, perhaps in August and September of the same year.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.P: My Department make special arrangements each year to enable candidates who are ill to take all or part of their examinations in hospital, subject to their doing their examinations at the appointed time. Approximately 70 such cases were dealt with in each of the years 1991 and 1992 in State examinations.

In the case of candidates who are taken ill during the course of the examinations, and are therefore unable to take the examinations at the appointed time, it is not feasible to provide replacement papers in either the junior or leaving certificate examinations.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Cloontruskert (Roscommon) School.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline his intentions regarding the appointment of a third assistant teacher at Cloontruskert national school, Lanesboro, County Roscommon for which the school board of management has applied; and if he will outline his views on whether the exceptional circumstances that exist in this school demand the urgent appointment of a third assistant at this school.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.P: The staffing of a national school is determined by the valid enrolment in the school on the previous 30 September. This is in accordance with the agreement on staffing made between the Government and the INTO.

MainHeading.P: In the case of Cloontruskert national school there were 92 pupils validly enrolled on 30 September 1992, which warrants a staff of principal plus two assistants for the 1992-93 school year.
Only in exceptional circumstances can pupils who are repeating sixth standard be counted as validly enrolled for staffing and other purposes.
I regret that the appointment of a third assistant is not warranted in this case.

Qst.askee: Minister for Tourism, Transport and Communications
Qst.Quest: if she will clarify the situation in relation to EC Regulation SI 59/1991 relating to existing bus owners continuing in business; if she will outline the way in which she proposes to implement this without making many existing bus owners redundant; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Tourism, Transport and Communications (Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn) Máire Geoghegan-Quinn
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism, Transport and Communications (Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn)
Speaker.P: Regulations were made in March 1991 to give effect to an EC Directive on access to the occupation of road haulage operator and road passenger transport operator. The passenger regulations require that all existing bus operators must hold a road passenger transport operator's licence.
To obtain a licence, operators must satisfy the EC requirements of good repute, appropriate financial standing and professional competence.

The professional competence requirement can be met by the licence applicant obtaining a certificate of competence himself or by engaging the holder of such a certificate as his transport manager. Certificates of competence are obtained normally by attending a course and by being successful in the relevant examination organised by the Chartered Institute of Transport in Ireland on my behalf.
The good repute and appropriate financial standing requirements are matters personal to each particular operator.

Following consultation with representative bodies of the road passenger operators, the effective date of the regulations for existing operators, has been postponed on two occasions and an extra course and examination were arranged to cater for those who needed to obtain a certificate of professional competence. This course and examination were in addition to the usual ones held twice annually. I am pleased to note that the success rate in these recent examinations was of the order of 90 per cent.
I am fully satisfied that existing bus operators have been given ample opportunity to meet the necessary requirements.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Children's Rights Charter.

Qst.Quest: if the Government have considered laying down a charter of children's rights; if so, if he will outline the results of such considerations and the desirability of a charter of this nature; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Connell) John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: The State signed the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child on 30 September 1990.

MainHeading.P: This Convention lays down universal standards for the treatment of children while acknowledging different economic, social and cultural values. The main provisions of the Convention deal with the inherent right to life and development of the child, the right of the child to express an opinion in any matter affecting the child, the adoption of children, health care, education, non-discrimination, the prohibition of torture or other cruel treatment and the right to protection from all types of abuse, including drugs, and exploitation.
Relevant provisions of the Convention were taken into account in the Adoption Act, 1991, and the Child Care Act, 1991.
I understand from my colleague the Minister for Foreign Affairs that the Convention is expected to be ratified shortly by the State.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Part-Time Workers.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline the situation in relation to the Part-time Workers Bill and home helps; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Connell) John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: The general objective of the Worker Protection (Regular Part-time Employees) Act, 1991, was to extend the entitlements provided for in certain “parent” Acts such as the Holiday Employees Act and the Maternity Protection Act to which some regular part-time employees had been excluded on the basis of the hours thresholds contained therein. While the 1991 Act amended the scope of these Acts, it did not change definitions of employee status or relationships. Therefore, persons who were excluded from the terms of the “parent” Acts by conditions other than hours thresholds, remain excluded.

MainHeading.P: The home help service is operated through a wide range of agencies. The voluntary nature of the service, which involves a large element of social commitment, is underlined by the fact that a significant proportion of part-time home helps are engaged on a voluntary basis. In the Eastern Health Board area, the service is provided wholly by voluntary groups. It is not possible arising from the diverse contractual arrangements involved to give a general assessment on the application of the terms of the Act to the home help service.

However, the Worker Protection (Regular Part-time Employees) Act, 1991, does provide a procedure for disputes concerning qualifying criteria through the Employment Appeals Tribunal. I understand also that advice on the matter is available from the Department of Labour.

Qst.Quest: if he will make a statement on the recent report by a person (details supplied) where he found that infection was present in 69 per cent of patients who died in the intensive care units of the Meath and Adelaide Hospitals in Dublin 8 within the last 12 months and said that infection represents a major problem for hospital intensive care units generally; and if he will outline the steps he has taken to improve the situation.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Connell) John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: The recent report by a consultant anaesthetist in the Meath Hospital quantifies, for the first time, the levels of infection within the intensive care unit of the hospital. The purpose of this audit was to critically analyse the practices within the unit in order to identify areas of possible improvement, and to review hospital policy regarding infection control.

The audit took place over the calendar period 1990-91, and one of the findings revealed that infection was present in 69 per cent of patients who died in the unit, during that period. The consultant who prepared the report has confirmed infection was not the cause of death in these patients. Critically ill patients are more susceptible to infection and are less able to fight it, and this is a major problem in intensive care units worldwide. The mortality rate within the unit for the 1990-91 period was 17 per cent, and this compares favourably with the rate in similar sized, good quality units in the United Kingdom.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Emergency Plans.

Qst.Quest: if he will make a statement on the recent report by a person (details supplied) which stated that a detailed survey of the emergency plans of four local authorities and one health board has revealed little or no co-ordinated emergency planning between the country's health boards, local authorities and gardaí; and if he will make a statement on the matter.
if he proposes to ensure that an updated disaster plan for the Cork-Kerry region will be put in place in view of the apparent shortcomings in the present plan.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Connell) John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 223 and 229 together.

Within a framework approved by Government in 1984 each health board has developed its own plan for the specific response of the health services should a major emergency occur. The role of the health board includes the provision of medical assistance, ambulance transport and casualty evacuation, hospital treatment and community, medical and welfare service. In addition, the emergency plans of the local authorities and the Garda are designed in such a way as to link in with the health board plan. It is the combination of the plans of each of the services which forms the overall emergency plan.

I understand that the health board plans have worked well on those occasions where unfortunately they had to be implemented. They are kept under review and are updated on a regular basis in the light of experience gained in this country and abroad.

MainHeading.P: The ongoing co-ordination of the plans of each emergency service is a matter for the Inter-Departmental Committee on Peacetime Emergencies. This committee meets to discuss ways of improving existing arrangements and of increasing co-operation and contact between the services.

The Southern Health Board's major emergency plan is revised annually. The last revision was issued in November 1991. The board participate in exercises with the other emergency services and are involved in regular liaison and discussion with local authorities and the Garda Síochána.

I am not aware that any shortcomings have been found in the Southern Health Board's major emergency plan. However, if the Deputy has any information in this regard he should make it available and I will raise the matter with the board. In the light of the Deputy's question I shall seek further assurance from the other health boards.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Malpractice Law Suits.

Qst.Quest: if he will make a statement on the recent comments by a person (details supplied) that after the United States, Ireland has the worst record in the world for malpractice law suits; and if he will outline the steps he proposes to take to deal with this issue, especially in view of the huge increases in medical defence fees being paid by his Department which has increased from £0.3 million in 1987 to close on £14 million in 1992.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Connell) John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: I am not in a position to refute the claim that Ireland has the worst record in the world after the United States for malpractice law suits. In any event, the number of law suits taken is not an indicator of the number of claims made against medical practitioners or the number of cases settled out of court. The general view of the profession in Ireland is that the Irish claims made experience is at least comparable to or possibly worse than the United Kingdom trend. However, the statistical facts in the whole area of medical litigation are notoriously difficult to establish. Following an announcement in December 1991 by the medical defence organisations that massive increases in medical defence fees were imminent, an inter-departmental working group was established to examine all areas of medical indemnity insurance.

MainHeading.P: The group focused initially on non-consultant hospital doctors as a homogeneous grouping within the medical profession for medical indemnity purposes. As a result, I am pleased to say that a new medical indemnity scheme has been arranged with the Medical Protection Society from 1 July 1992 for NCHDs and community medical and dental staff. The net effect to the individual is that he-she is no longer required to make any payment for indemnity cover. Savings will also accrue to the State as tax concessions will no longer be payable to individuals. The working group is currently finalising its report on all aspects of medical negligence and the various means of providing indemnity.

I look forward to receiving the working group's report and I can assure the Deputy that I will take immediate steps to initiate whatever action is recommended for cost containment in the whole area of medical indemnity.

Qst.Quest: if he will make a statement on recent comments by a person (details supplied) that his Department should close down one of the country's undergraduate medical schools and in its place establish a post-graduate training centre; and if he has any plans in this regard.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Connell) John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: My Department have no direct function in the decision on whether to establish or close down an undergraduate medical school. This is a matter for the Higher Education Authority and the Department of Education.

The promotion and development of postgraduate medical and dental education is the statutory function of the Postgraduate Medical and Dental Board. The board has recently been reappointed and has set itself the task of undertaking a major policy review in the whole area of postgraduate education with a view to identifying needs. I have no doubt that the suggestion for a national postgraduate education centre will receive due consideration as part of this process.
I look forward to examining the board's findings in due course.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - ENT Services.

Qst.Quest: if he will carry out an investigation into a report by the Royal Academy of Medicine which found that hardly any of the £100,000 allocated to the ear, nose and throat services prior to the last general election actually went to the services; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

if he will outline the proposals, if any, he has to deal with the serious situation in the ear, nose and throat specialty in Ireland especially arising from a recent study which shows major deficiencies in the provision of services in many areas particularly in the Southern Health Board area where only one full-time public ear, nose and throat consultant exists for half a million patients; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

if he will make a statement on a recent survey carried out of 17 ear, nose and throat units around Ireland which shows that audiology facilities in Irish acute hospitals are now at Third World levels; and the plans, if any, he has in relation to the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Connell) John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 232, 233 and 234 together.

With regard to ENT services in the Southern Health Board area, the position is that the regional unit is located at the South Infirmary-Victoria Hospital in Cork. There are two full-time and one part-time ENT consultants attached to this unit. The Deputy will be interested to know that the South Infirmary — Victoria Hospitals' revenue allocation for 1992 includes a sum of £0.150 million for the further development of the ENT service at the hospital. My Department has also approved a post of senior audiometrician and four additional nurses for the ENT unit at this hospital.

MainHeading.P: The Deputy will also be interested to know that the Southern Health Boards revenue allocation for 1992 includes provision for the development of an ENT service at Tralee General Hospital. In this context, my Department issued financial clearance to the Southern Health Board to proceed with arrangements for the appointment of an ENT consultant at Tralee General Hospital. I understand that Comhairle na nOspidéal has now given approval to the board to proceed with the filling of this post.

With regard to ENT services nationally my Department has recognised the need for further improvement in the service and this has been reflected in the 1992 Health Estimates. In addition to the developments in ENT in the Southern Health Board area specific provision has also been made for the development of ENT services in the North Eastern Health Board, the Western Health Board and the Midland Health Board areas. I am confident that these measures will significantly improve the service for patients requiring ENT treatment.
Audiology services are provided by health board community care programmes, the National Rehabilitation Board, special audiology clinics and ENT departments of major acute general hospitals.

The question of resourcing technical staff levels in hospitals is primarily a matter to be addressed by hospital authorities, subject to their prioritising their perceived relative needs within the general environment of deployment of financial resources and current employment control procedures. More generally, the national population base has certain limiting implications for the range of technical, vocational and professional courses which can reasonably be provided within third level colleges on a continuous structured basis. Courses of training for careers as an audiologist or as an audiological technician, audiometrician, are available in various centres in the United Kingdom, through no such courses are available here. In common with a number of other specialist career areas some difficulty has tended to be experienced over the years in the recruitment of audiology support staff to centres in the public health service here. Salary levels for audiological technicians are in line with these for many broadly comparable health service employees. The difficulty in recruiting personnel would derive from a number of factors.

The additional funds allocated in 1989 to reduce unacceptable long waiting times resulted in a reduction of almost 10 per cent in the numbers of patients on the waiting list for ENT treatment during the period April 1990 to February 1991.

Qst.Quest: if, in view of the increasing problem of the spread of AIDS, he will outline his views on whether it is necessary to establish a special unit to deal with this problem.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Connell) John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: Effective planning, implementation and review structures are in place which are addressing the serious public health challenges which AIDS/HIV represent. As Minister for Health I am directly involved in the development of a comprehensive and integrated national AIDS policy in terms of prevention, treatment, care and rehabilitation. The National AIDS Strategy Committee, of which I am Chairman, has developed a number of strategies to implement national policy goals on a priority and on a multi-sectoral basis. The Deputy will be aware of these strategies which concern: the care and management of persons with HIV/AIDS, HIV/AIDS surveillance, education and prevention strategies and measures to avoid discrimination.

The implementation of the strategies which has received a major additional investment of £3.3 million this year is currently being undertaken by statutory and voluntary agencies. A prevention programme by way of information and education is an integral feature of the on-going work of my Department's Health Promotion Unit. The pace of progress in all areas dealing with the AIDS/HIV problem has been impressive this year.

In view of the current structures which facilitate the effective development and implementation of our National AIDS Strategy on a multi-sectoral basis and in a co-ordinated manner, I would not propose establishing a specific unit to deal with the problem. I accept however that improved co-ordination and integration of services and programmes is necessary and my Department is currently examining how best to achieve these objectives.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - GMS Review Group Recommendations.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline the impact that the recommendations of the Review Group on General Medical Services has had on the continuing increased costs of drugs in the GMS; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Connell) John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: In the course of the 1990-91 GMS review, a drugs strategy was agreed between management and the IMO for dealing with the problem of the increasing cost of prescribing in the general medical services scheme. While this strategy needs to be given some time to achieve results, I am concerned at the continuing upward trend in prescribing levels in the scheme. I have already indicated that as part of the current negotiations on the GMS contract review, further measures need to be agreed which will achieve safer and more cost-effective prescribing. I am pleased that both sides in the current review negotiations have committed themselves to this process and I am confident that a workable plan will be agreed for dealing with this difficult problem.

Qst.Quest: if he has satisfied himself that there are sufficient welfare officers to assess married couples who apply to adopt a child; and if he will outline the waiting period for assessment.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Connell) John F. O'Connell
Speaker.P: I presume the Deputy is referring to the situation in the Eastern Health Board area where couples are waiting to be assessed for a foreign adoption.

This backlog has risen as a result of the large initial rush of applications for assessment following the enactment of the Adoption Act, 1991, which imposed for the first time a statutory duty on health boards to carry out foreign adoption assessments.

The Eastern Health Board is committed to clearing the backlog as soon as practicable. This is reflected in the fact that it now has four social workers carrying out assessments and that it expects to be in a position to assign a fifth social worker to the task this month. These measures are having a big impact on the current waiting list and demonstrate the health board's commitment to the early completion of all outstanding assessments.

I fully appreciate the anxiety of the couples concerned to have their assessments started and I would ask them to be patient a little longer while the positive steps being taken by the health board on their behalf bring about an improvement in the situation.

the reason his Department are delaying the enactment of regulations to allow taxi ranks to be created in the towns of Mullingar and Athlone in County Westmeath; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: whether the Review Committee on the Taxi Service has presented any recommendations; and if he will outline when he intends to implement reforms.
if he will outline the position in relation to proposed changes in the issuing and administration of (1) taxi plates and (2) hackney licences; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Smith) Michael Smith
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 258, 259, 260 and 266 together.

The report of the committee which carried out a review of the law applying to the operation of small public service vehicles was published on 1 July and is available in the Oireachtas Library. The report contains a total of 64 recommendations. Because of the extent of the changes recommended and the high level of interest in the matter, I intend to allow a period for interested persons and bodies to consider the issues, and to make submissions to me, before I decide whether to implement the main recommendations. These recommendations do not necessily represent the only way forward and I will be looking at all the options, taking account of any views which interested persons or bodies may wish to offer.

MainHeading.P: In conjunction with publication of the report, I decided that some of the recommendations should be implemented immediately and I made regulations on 1 July which provide for the grant, by the Garda Commissioner, of 50 new licences for wheelchair accessible taxis in the Dublin taximeter area and for the removal of the moratorium on the grant of new taxi and private hire (hackney) licences throughout the country which was introduced last October. Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the serious difficulties being experienced by industrialists where toxic waste is creating human hazards; and whether he has any legislative proposals to resolve the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Miss Harney) Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Miss Harney)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Miss Harney)
Speaker.P: Waste producers are primarily responsible for the safe disposal of their wastes. The appropriate local authority has statutory functions in relation to toxic and dangerous waste planning and control within its functional area. MainHeading.P: 267. Mr. J. Bruton asked the Minister for the Environment if he will outline the recommendations made by the Employment Task Force in regard to the National Roads Authority.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Smith) Michael Smith
Speaker.P: The recommendations of the Tenth Report of the Task Force on Employment in regard to the National Roads Authority (NRA) can be summarised as follows:
1. That the Roads Bill, 1991 be enacted and the proposed NRA be established during the spring 1992 sitting of the Dáil.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Smith) Michael Smith
Speaker.P: The Operational Programme on Peripherality 1989 to 1993 is the main vehicle for EC Structural Fund assistance for roads, airports, seaports and other transport infrastructure under the present Community Support Framework for Ireland. The Programme comprises two sub-programmes:

—the peripherality sub-programme concerns transport investments which contribute to off-setting the impact of Ireland's peripheral location, including an investment of £549.02 million in the development of national primary roads. The European Regional Development Fund contribution towards this investment will amount to £393.57 million.

—the sub-regional development sub-programme concerns transport investments of major significance to the development of industry and tourism at sub-regional and local levels. Investment in road improvements qualifying for European Regional Development Fund assistance under this sub-programme comprises:

MainHeading.P: Progress on the programme is being monitored by a committee comprised of representatives of the social partners, the implementing agencies, the EC Commission, the European Investment Bank, and Government Departments. The committee recently carried out a comprehensive mid-term review of the programme which confirmed that investment outturns in relation to road development in the period to end 1991 were on target. The commitment given in the 1989 budget that £150 million would be provided over three years in discretionary grants to county councils for regional and county roads was more than fulfilled. MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Human Rights Violations in Iran.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. O'Keeffe Mr. J. O'Keeffe
Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the violations of and departures from human rights principles in Iran which involve executions, torture and inhuman punishments; and whether Ireland and the EC have taken any steps in response to this situation.

if he will make a statement regarding the current human rights situation in Iran with particular reference to the findings in recent reports on the matter by United Nations special representatives; and if he will outline the representations he made to the Iranian authorities in the matter in course of his recent visit.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 281 and 300 together.

I am fully aware of the report made by the United Nations Special Representative, Mr. Galindo Pohl, on the human rights situation in Iran in 1991. The Minister for Foreign Affairs paid an official visit to Iran from 3 to 5 March during which he raised the issue of human rights with the Iranian authorities.

MainHeading.P: Concurrently with that visit, Ireland and the other member states of the European Community co-sponsored a draft resolution on human rights in Iran at the United Nations Commission on Human Rights, in Geneva. That resolution was adopted on 4 March.
It expressed deep concern at the continuing reports of violations of human rights in Iran and grave concern at the fact that the application of the death penalty had not diminished, but increased.

The resolution renewed for a further year the mandate of the special representative to report on the human rights situation in Iran and requested him to submit an interim report to the United Nations General Assembly. This means that human rights in Iran will be examined by the General Assembly in the autumn.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Western European Union Meetings.

Qst.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Qst.Quest: if he will list each meeting of the Western European Union at which Ireland has been an observer; if he will outline (a) the date, (b) the location and purpose of each meeting and (c) by whom Ireland was represented; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: Ireland has attended three meetings of the WEU's Ministerial council as an observer.

Two of these, on 19 September 1991 in the Hague and on 30 September 1991 in Brussels, considered the conflict in Yugoslavia and the steps the WEU might take to support the European Community's peace process including its Monitor Mission. In the event no such steps were taken.
The Government's decision to attend as an observer was based on its desire to be fully informed of all developments that might have a bearing on the Community's peace process in Yugoslavia.

MainHeading.P: The third meeting took place at the time of the Maastricht Council on 9/10 December 1991. At that meeting, the WEU discussed its future relations with the European Union and the invitation to be issued to members of the European Union to become members or observers of the WEU. This invitation is contained in a Declaration by the WEU which was noted by the Intergovernmental Conference of the member States of the EC.

Ireland was represented as an observer at all three meetings by the then Minister for Foreign Affairs Mr. Gerard Collins T.D. An ad hoc meeting at official level which prepared the draft of the WEU Declaration and took place at the same time as the Maastricht Council was attended as an observer by an official from the Department of Foreign Affairs.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Cambodian Landmines Hazard.

Qst.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the dangers still posed to Cambodian civilisation by the presence of landmines which are estimated to have led to the loss of limbs of some 6,000 people last year; if he will urge the provision of additional resources for the UN teams charged with the task of removing the mines; if he will urge an international ban on the manufacture, possession, transfer and sale of these landmines; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Afairs (Mr. Andrews) Minister for Foreign Afairs (Mr. Andrews)
Speaker.P: The widespread presence of unexploded landmines throughout the Cambodian countryside is a real danger to the lives and limbs of all the people of Cambodia. The problem posed by these landmines is fully recognised by the international community and is a matter of major concern to the United Nations.

MainHeading.P: In recognition of this, one of the first tasks undertaken by the United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia was the establishment in April of this year of the Cambodian Mine Action Centre. The function of the Centre is to assist in undertaking long-term programmes in mine-awareness, mine-marking and mine-clearance. The Centre also trains civilians in mine-avoidance techniques. The UN considers that the Centre's programmes are proceeding well.

UNTAC has already deployed mine-clearing teams in Cambodia and is engaged in training additional Cambodians so that further mine-training teams can be deployed in the coming months. The UN estimates that 5,000 Cambodians will have been trained in mine-clearing by the end of the year.

UNTAC has concentrated its initial mine-clearing work on the main roads; recently, the whole of route 69, from Sisophon to the Thai border, has been cleared and the clearing of other main roads, particularly those being used by returning refugees is being given priority.

As regards a ban on landmines, I think it is worth noting that the problem has been specifically addressed by the UN Secretary General in his recent report “Agenda For Peace”. I would hope that this will lead to this serious matter being given further consideration by the United Nations.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Plenipotentiary Appointment.

Qst.hpid: Mr. M. Higgins Mr. M. Higgins
Qst.Quest: if he will outline the date on which a plenipotentiary was appointed for the purpose of negotiation of the Treaty on European Union; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: The Treaty on European Union was negotiated at two intergovernmental conferences which dealt separately with political union and economic and monetary union. This is in accordance with the practice in the case of all such treaties where negotiation takes place in a conference of representatives of the Governments of the member States.

MainHeading.P: Ireland was represented at the intergovernmental conference on political union by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and at the intergovernmental conference on economic and monetary union by the Minister for Finance. The Treaty was finalised at the Maastricht European Council on 9-10 December where Ireland was represented by the then Taoiseach, accompanied by the then Minister for Foreign Affairs and by the Minister for Finance.

The Treaty was formally adopted and signed at Maastricht on 7 February by Plenipotentiaries from the various member States. In the case of Ireland the Plenipotentiaries were Bertie Ahern, Minister for Finance, and Gerard Collins, the then Minister for Foreign Affairs. They were appointed as Plenipotentiaries on 6th day of February, 1992.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Irish Students in Germany.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. O'Keeffe Mr. J. O'Keeffe
Qst.Quest: whether, in relation to the report which he has received from the Embassy in Bonn concerning the difficulties being experienced by Irish students in the Munich area, he will now outline the problems and difficulties which have been highlighted in the Embassy's detailed report and the actions proposed in that report to overcome these problems and dificulties.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: The report from the Embassy in Bonn indicates that the main problem facing Irish students in Munich is their difficulty in obtaining suitable low-cost accommodation. In addition, for a variety of reasons, holiday employment is scarcer than usual in Munich this year. These difficulties were compounded by the fact that many of the students lacked sufficient information about living and working conditions in Germany and were unprepared for the practical problems which they might encounter.

MainHeading.P: The Embassy official who visited Munich for four days last week spent a considerable amount of time discussing their problems with the large body of Irish students and advising them how best they might improve their position. His discussions with campsite officials, various officials dealing with local employment, and the local police also helped to sensitise the authorities in Munich to the problems being exprienced by Irish students. The visit by the Embassy official appears to have dealt with the more accute aspects of the problem; however, the Embassy will keep in close touch with the situation and will send an officer to Munich again if necessary.

The experience in Munich highlights in particular the need for proper preparation on the part of young people travelling abroad for summer holiday work. I have asked my Department to examine, together with other Departments involved, any further steps that might be taken to address this issue.
