Qst.hpid: Mr. J. O'Keeffe Mr. J. O'Keeffe
Qst.Quest: if he will outline the steps taken by Ireland to highlight the savage repression of the military régime in Burma and to ostracise them in the international community.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: The situation in Burma, both in relation to human rights abuses and in the failure of the military junta to respect the results of the May 1990 election, continues to be a matter of grave concern to the Government.

Ireland, together with our partners in the Community, issued three statements this year expressing our continuing concern at the repressive policies of the Burmese régime. On 20 March we expressed our sense of horror at the actions of the régime which led to over 100,000 Rohingya Muslims fleeing from Burma to Bangladesh. On 15 April we urged the Burmese Government to refrain from further military and any other repressive action against minorities in Burma.

On 16 June we noted recent measures adopted by the State Law and Order Restoration Council (SLORC) involving the release of some political prisoners including senior members of the National League for Democracy and the permission for Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi's husband and children to visit her. However, we and our Community partners stressed that the development of constructive relations depended on Burma becoming a democratic state and respecting human rights, in accordance with the UN Charter and universally accepted standards.
In addition, at this year's session of the UN Commission on Human Rights in Geneva Ireland co-sponsored a strong resolution condemning the human rights situation in Burma.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Departmental Legislation.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Higgins Mr. J. Higgins
Qst.Quest: if he will give details of the legislation for which he is responsible enacted by the Oireachtas which has not yet gone into effect; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. Higgins Mr. J. Higgins
Qst.Quest: if he will give details in respect of his Department of (a) the legislation promised in the Oireachtas since 1989 and (b) the legislation introduced to the Oireachtas; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: I propose to answer Questions Nos. 297 and 298 together. The position regarding legislation promised or introduced since 1989 is as follows:
Educational Exchange (Ireland and the United States of America) Act, 1991

This Act was signed into law by the President on 28 May 1991. The Act provided for the establishment of the Ireland-United States Commission for Educational Exchange to replace An Bord Scoláireachtaí Cómalairte (The Scholarship Exchange Board) which, since 1957, had administered the Fulbright Programme of academic exchanges between Ireland and the US The Commission was established by Ministerial Order on 3 February of this year.
11th Amendment of the Constitution Bill 1992

Ireland signed the Treaty on European Union at Maastricht on 7 February 1992. Under Article R of the Treaty, member states undertook to ratify the Treaty in accordance with their respective constitutional requirements and to complete those procedures before 1 January 1993.

MainHeading.P: As a first stage in Ireland's ratification procedures the Minister for Foreign Affairs presented the Eleventh Amendment of the Constitution Bill, 1992, in April 1992. The Bill provided for an amendment to Article 29 of the Constitution to allow the State to ratify the Treaty on European Union and become a member of the Union. The amendment also allowed the State to ratify the agreement relating to Community Patents.

The Bill completed its passage through both Houses of the Oireachtas on 15 May 1992 and, following the referendum on 18 June 1992, it will shortly be presented for the President's signature in accordance with the relevant constitutional provision.

The next stage in Ireland's ratification procedures will require an amendment to the European Communities Act, 1972 to take account of the Treaty. Draft Heads of a Bill are being prepared and will be presented to Government shortly. It is intended at this stage that a Bill will be presented early in the autumn.
There is no legislation, for which the Department of Foreign Affairs is responsible and which has been enacted by the Oireachtas, which is not in operation.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - UN Team in Iraq.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline the progress made by the United Nations team in Iraq in identifying and destroying weapons of mass destruction; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: The United Nations Special Commission reported last month that, until there is full disclosure by Iraq of its proscribed weapons programme as required under Security Council resolutions, it will not be in a position to state categorically that Iraq no longer has the capability to produce such weapons.

The Special Commission has, however, verified the destruction of ballistic missile production equipment in Iraq and, provided that what has been verified represents the essence of Iraq's ballistic missile production capability, the Special Commission is confident that Iraq's capability in this area has been destroyed.

MainHeading.P: I regret to say I have seen reports that Iraq, on Sunday 5 July, refused UN inspectors permission to enter a Government building as part of their task of overseeing the dismantling of weapons of mass destruction by Iraq.

It is essential that Iraq co-operate fully with the UN Special Commission in the discharge of its mandate to ensure the elimination of Iraq's weapons of mass destruction. The Special Commission has pursued that mandate with great vigour and last weekend's reported event is the latest example of its commitment to that task.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Milk Hygiene Regulations.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline the implications for Irish agriculture of the recent European Council of Ministers agreement introducing two milk hygiene regulations relating to milk manufacturing and heat treated liquid milk.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. Walsh) Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. Walsh)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. Walsh)
Speaker.P: Following the recent Council agreement to which the Deputy refers, a single EC Directive now covers the health and hygiene standards applicable to the production, processing and sale of all heat treated milk and milk based products. The second Directive merely provides for the possibility of certain temporary derogations from the terms of the principal measure.

MainHeading.P: The harmonisation of milk production and processing standards throughout the Community is in keeping with the move towards the completion of the internal market and as such will facilitate intra-Community trade in this sector. MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Noxious Weeds.

Qst.Quest: whether he intends to take action on the serious problem being suffered by a person (details supplied) in County Leitrim because of a proliferation of noxious weeds; and if his attention has been drawn to the fact that (1) this problem has been recurring for a number of years and (2) action was taken in 1985 and in 1988 but no further action has been taken although a form NW.3 was sent to his Department on two further occasions; the reason no further action has been taken; and whether he now intends to take action as this situation is causing great hardship to neighbouring owners.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. Walsh) Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. Walsh)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. Walsh)
Speaker.P: In modern standards of farm management, farmers are aware of the adverse effect of noxious weeds on farm output. The vast majority keep weeds under control but, since they are indigenous and universally occurring plants, it is not possible to achieve eradication and my Department does not have the resources to enforce total destruction of these weeds. The policy is to advise farmers through publicity, including through the advisory work of Teagasc in the course of farm visits.

MainHeading.P: The case involved in the Deputy's question relates to a persistent complaint by one person against a neighbouring farmer. The land of the complainant is a private amenity garden and not an agricultural holding. The Department has pursued the case regularly over many years and has achieved a positive response from the farmer who has made considerable and successful efforts to keep the weeds under control, particularly during the seeding season. My Department will continue to keep contact with this particular case.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Recognition of Foreign Divorces.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline whether, when an Irish citizen obtains a foreign divorce, through accommodation address or otherwise, and then remarries outside the State, this marriage is recognised for social welfare purposes; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: Although there is no provision for obtaining a divorce in Ireland, the law does recognise foreign divorces in certain circumstances. In deciding an application for a social welfare payment, where a foreign divorce is involved, the Department must have regard to the status of the individual under the laws of the State, in considering the application. The legal provision relating to foreign divorces are to be found in the Domicile and Recognition of Foreign Divorces Act, 1986 and not in Social Welfare legislation.

Generally, if a divorce is recognised in the State, it is also recognised for social welfare purposes. In these circumstances if the person remarries, that marriage will be recognised for social welfare purposes.

Qst.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the unacceptable situation which has arisen from the changes made in the Social Welfare Act, 1992 regarding maternity benefit which now means that pregnant women who are not in employment, or who do not have a job to return to after the birth of the child, are denied maternity benefit and are having to continue to sign on at employment exchanges right up to confinement and immediately after birth in order to continue receiving unemployment assistance; if he considers this acceptable; if he will now amend the scheme; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: Prior to the Social Welfare Act 1992, there were two maternity benefit schemes. The scheme for women in employment covered women who qualified for leave from work under the Maternity Protection of Employees Acts, 1981 and 1991. The other scheme catered for women workers who did not so qualify but who satisfied the relevant contribution conditions. Women claiming unemployment benefit or disability benefit could transfer to this scheme for the relevant period. Women claiming unemployment assistance would not generally fulfil the contribution conditions for maternity benefit and would remain on unemployment assistance for the period concerned.

The Social Welfare Act, 1992, rationalised the schemes, in the light of the extension of entitlement to maternity benefit and other social insurance payments to all workers earning £25 a week or more including part-time workers. Under these arrangements the maternity benefit scheme for women in employment was extended to women in employments not covered by the Maternity Protection of Employees Acts, 1981 and 1991.

MainHeading.P: Arrangements were made at the same time for women on unemployment benefit and disability benefit, who had hitherto availed of the general maternity scheme, to remain on those payments for the period immediately before and after the birth of a child. In order to eliminate the necessity for pregnant women and women who have recently given birth to attend for weekly signing at their local employment offices, new flexible signing arrangements have just been introduced. Under these new arrangements, pregnant women will be required to sign a declaration of their availability for employment six weeks before their expected date of confinement. Thereafter, they will receive their weekly payments by post. A second declaration will be sent by post to be signed after the confinement, which will continue the arrangements for the following six weeks. The question of the claimant's continued availability for employment will not fall to be examined until the end of the 12 week period. The effect of these new arrangements is that women claiming unemployment benefit or unemployment assistance will not now be required to sign on in the periods immediately before and after their confinement.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Policing of Toxic Substances.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline the present position regarding the policing of toxic dangerous substances in industry and in storage; and whether they comply with EC standards.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Cowen) Brian Cowen
Speaker.P: The National Authority for Occupational Safety and Health are statutorily responsible for the administration and enforcement of occupational safety and health legislation. This legislation includes the Safety, Health and Welfare at Work Act, 1989, and statutory regulations which give effect to a wide range of EC directives on the handling, use, transport, storage, classification, packaging, labelling and so on of dangerous substances as well as the prevention and control of the major accident hazards of certain industrial activities.

MainHeading.P: The authority's inspectors regularly inspect workplaces for compliance with the legislation. Compliance with the EC requirements is normally satisfactory. However, where necessary, the inspectors would use one of the enforcement procedures available to them under the 1989 Act such as the serving of improvement notices, prohibition notices or the initiation of prosecution procedures.

Qst.Quest: if he has applied for EC funding under the NOW programme to enable Irish women to share in the anticipated benefits of the Single Market.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Cowen) Brian Cowen
Speaker.P: NOW is a European Community initiative which aims to promote equal opportunities for women in the field of employment and vocational training. All projects supported under NOW will undertake joint activity with another European Community member state.

An operational programme for NOW was submitted to the European Commission in October 1992. A European Commission decision on this operational programme was reached on the 29 December 1991, in which Ireland was allocated IR£3.2 million assistance from EC Structural Funds.
Thirteen projects are formally approved for funding and are commencing activity. A further number of projects will commence activity in the near future.
Given the high level of interest in Ireland in the NOW initiative, I have written to Commissioner Papandreou seeking additional EC funds for NOW. I am hopeful of a positive response to this request.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the fact that, following a direction from his Department, a number of social employment schemes in the central Dublin area where arbitrarily terminated, or frozen causing disruption amongst the voluntary organisations, who depend on the services of the social employment scheme to carry out their essential work; if he will outline the steps, if any, he will take to ensure that FAS have the necessary funds required to enable them to administer the social employment schemes on a sound and effective basis; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

if he will outline where the extra 5,000 social employment scheme places, recently promised by him are to be located, and if he has given any directions to FÁS to alter or change the way in which the present social employment scheme participants and supervisory organisations are employed and retained; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Cowen) Brian Cowen
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 355 and 357 together. The operation of the scheme within the agreed funding level with regard to the level of intake and the approval or renewal of projects is a day-to-day matter for FÁS. Directions were not given by my Department.

The 1992 Exchequer allocation for the social employment scheme is £72.9 million compared with £59.545 million in 1991. The 1992 allocation makes up for the loss of £13 million approximately European Social Fund aid in 1991. I have indicated on a number of occasions that the 1992 allocation was intended to provide 11,000 man-years activity. I am optimistic, that in fact it will be possible to generate 11,300 approximately man-years activity in 1992 with the allocation of £72.9 million.

I must re-emphasise that the scheme was never intended to provide funding on a continuing basis for particular projects. It would be more appropriate for voluntary organisations providing services on a continuing basis to seek sources of State funding from sources relating to the area in which they are operating, e.g. the Arts, health, etc.

Qst.Quest: if he has any proposals to review and revise the way in which replies to parliamentary questions are prepared and finalised within his Department in order to ensure accuracy, clarity and democratic accountability in view of the concerns recently expressed about the inadequacy of parliamentary replies; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Cowen) Brian Cowen
Speaker.P: I have no proposals to review and revise the procedures in relation to dealing with parliamentary questions in my Department. Great care is taken in providing accurate and comprehensive replies to Deputies' questions. I am satisfied that there is no cause for change in the present system.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Cowen) Brian Cowen
Speaker.P: There are no special policy advisers employed in my Department.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. O'Keeffe Mr. J. O'Keeffe
Qst.Quest: whether he has had discussions with any semi-State bodies with a view to increasing the number of places available for apprenticeship training.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Cowen) Brian Cowen
Speaker.P: Responsibility for the recruitment of apprentices rests with employers. I have not had discussions with any semi-State bodies about increasing the number of apprentices but, as an on-going process, FÁS encourage employers to take on the maximum possible numbers of apprentices.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. O'Keeffe Mr. J. O'Keeffe

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Cowen) Brian Cowen
Speaker.P: The intake of first year apprentices over each of the past five years is as follows: 1987, 2,955; 1988, 2,445; 1989, 2,663; 1990, 2,855; 1991, 2,919. A breakdown of these figures as requested by the Deputy is a day-to-day matter for FÁS.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Maximum Weight Reduction.

Qst.Quest: if he will reduce the maximum weight of 121 lbs. that a workman is required or allowed to lift.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Cowen) Brian Cowen
Speaker.P: Currently, under the Factories Act, 1955 (Manual Labour) (Maximum Weights and Transport) Regulations, 1972, (S.I. No. 283 of 1972), adult males employed in certain premises to which the Safety in Industry Acts, 1955 and 1980 apply may not be required to lift or carry a load weighing more than 55 kilograms or 121 lbs. This is without prejudice to the general requirement in section 67 (1) of the Factories Act, 1955, that a person may not be employed to lift, carry or move any load so heavy as to be likely to cause injury to him.

The National Authority for Occupational Safety and Health are considering proposals for new regulations to give effect by the end of this year to EC Council 90/269/EEC on the minimum health and safety requirements for the manual handling of loads where there is a risk particularly of back injury to workers. The existing regulations will be revoked on the coming into operation of the new regulations which will apply to all places of work.

MainHeading.P: Firstly, the Directive requires an employer to take appropriate measures or use appropriate means, in particular mechanical equipment, in order to avoid the need for the manual handling of loads by workers. Where such manual handling cannot be avoided the employer must make an assessment and take appropriate measures to remove or reduce the risk of injury. The assessment required must take into account several factors including the characteristics of the load e.g., weight, size and shape, the physical effort required e.g., too strenuous, unstable body posture, the characteristics of the working environment e.g., insufficient room, uneven floor and the requirements of the activity e.g., excessive lifting, rate of work as well as the specific risk factors which may affect the individual workers e.g., physically unsuited to tasks, insufficient training. The directive is based on modern ergonomic criteria which recognise that weight is one of the many factors only which may influence the risk of injury in the manual handling of loads. Accordingly, the directive refrains form stipulating absolute maximum weights to be applied.
The directive is of special significance in that its preventive approach relies more on the use of ergonomic assessment, mechanical aids and training than on human muscle power.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Health and Safety Regulation.

Qst.Quest: if he will change the health and safety regulation so that an inspector on inspection in a factory or premises would be obliged to (1) clearly identify himself by a name tag and (2) inform the safety official at the premises before any inspection takes place; and if he will alter the regulations to require the inspector to provide a copy of his report/recommendations at the premises to the safety officer of that premises.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Cowen) Brian Cowen
Speaker.P: Under the Safety, Health and Welfare at Work Act, 1989 responsibility for enforcement and inspection activities relating to occupational safety and health is a function of the National Authority for Occupational Safety and Health. Accordingly, the issues raised by the Deputy fall within the authority's remit.
I propose to send a copy of the question to the authority, request them to consider the issues raised and to provide the Deputy with a reply.
